The rain against the corrugated iron roof of the neighbour's extension was a sound from a past I couldn't seem to escape. It was a drumming, a frantic heartbeat that mimicked the one in my own chest the last time I saw him. Here, in my small room in South C, with its single window looking out onto a muddy lane and a perpetually barking dog, the past was a more solid presence than the chipped plaster on the walls. It had weight. It had the scent of Kaelo’s cologne, a sharp, citrusy thing he’d saved up for months to buy, and the warmth of his body asleep in the bed next to mine.

Our mothers had decided we would share a room. A pragmatic decision, born of a four-bedroom house that was suddenly too small for two families stitched together. My mother, Wanjiru, and his father, David, were so caught up in the giddy orbit of their new love that they saw no potential for friction, only harmony. “You’ll be brothers,” David had said, clapping us both on the shoulder, his voice booming with a kind of hope that felt both naïve and infectious. And for a long time, he was right. We were more than brothers. Kaelo was the anchor to my drifting boat, the bright, chaotic colour in my monochrome life.

I was the tutor. The quiet one, the reader, the one who navigated the shoals of calculus and chemistry with a grim determination. Kaelo was… Kaelo. He moved through the world as if it was a party thrown in his honour. Laughter trailed him like a cape. He collected friends the way other boys collected bottle caps, effortlessly, amassing a treasure trove of mismatched, loyal people. And I was his first, his most prized. The secret keeper. The homework fixer. The one who knew he was terrified of moths and that he hummed off-key when he thought no one was listening.

The rain fell harder, a silver sheet that blurred the world outside. I picked up the photograph from my desk, its edges softened with handling. It was from two years ago, a trip to Naivasha. We are sitting on the scratchy grass by the lake, Kaelo’s arm thrown around my shoulder, his head tilted towards mine. He is grinning, a wide, sun-splitting thing that shows the tiny gap between his front teeth. I am smiling too, a smaller, more contained version of his joy, but my eyes are fixed only on him. It was a moment of pure, uncomplicated happiness. A time before the fault line appeared, before the ground began to tremble beneath my feet. Before Anais.

It started, as most endings do, with a beginning. Kaelo had just scraped through his KCSEs, a feat he attributed entirely to my nightly drilling sessions. "Jonas, my brother, my saviour," he'd yelled, waving the results slip in the air. "Without you, I'd be selling roasted maize by the roadside!" He'd hugged me, lifting me off the ground in a whirlwind of relief and gratitude. In that moment, pressed against his chest, smelling the sweat and sun on his skin, the feeling that had been a quiet hum in my blood for years crescendoed into a roar. It was love. Not brotherly, not friendly. It was a deep, aching, terrifying love.

He was supposed to be studying business at Strathmore, a concession to his father. But Kaelo treated university like an extension of his social life. The campus was just a new, grander stage. And on that stage, he met them. The Karen set. Children of diplomats and politicians and old money, people who vacationed in Malindi as casually as we took a matatu into town. They drove cars that cost more than our house. They spoke with an accent that was a strange hybrid of British television and inherited entitlement.

The first time he brought one of them home, it was a boy named Seb. Seb had pale, freckled skin and a lazy, assessing gaze that made me feel like an interesting insect. He surveyed our living room, with its mismatched furniture and my mother's vibrant kitenge curtains, with a kind of detached amusement.

"So this is where you live, K," Seb said, drawing out the 'K' into a low drawl. "It's… cozy."

Kaelo, who had never once been ashamed of our home, flushed slightly. "It's home," he said, his voice a little too loud. "Jonas, this is Seb. We're in the same macroeconomics class."

"I'm his tutor, mostly," Seb added with a thin smile, looking at me. "He's a bright lad, just needs to apply himself."

I just nodded, the words sticking in my throat. I was used to being the smart one, the one Kaelo looked up to. But in Seb’s world, I was the help. Kaelo didn’t seem to notice the subtle shift, the re-categorization of my existence. He was too dazzled by Seb’s stories of polo matches and weekends in the Mara. He was a moth drawn to a brighter, more dangerous flame.

That night, the space between our beds in the room we still shared felt like a chasm. Kaelo was buzzing, tapping away on his phone, a small smile playing on his lips.

"Seb's hilarious," he said, not looking at me. "His dad is the ambassador for Sweden or something. They're having a party on Saturday. At their place. You should come, Jona."

"I don't think so," I said, turning to face the wall. "I have papers to mark." It was a lie. My weekend was a blank slate, as always.

"Oh. Okay." He sounded disappointed, but only for a second. The blue light of his phone illuminated his face, casting him in an alien glow. He was already somewhere else, in a world of embassy parties and casual wealth, a world where I had no place. I felt a cold dread seep into my bones. It was the first time he had ever accepted my refusal so easily. Usually, he would wheedle and bargain and tease until I gave in. But not this time. The thread was fraying.

The parties became a regular thing. Saturdays, then Fridays too. He started coming home late, smelling of expensive whiskey and a perfume that wasn't his. He'd stumble into our room, shedding clothes onto the floor, and fall into bed without a word. The late-night talks, the whispered confessions and shared jokes that had been the bedrock of our friendship, vanished. They were replaced by a silence that was louder than any argument. He started using their slang, calling things "peak" and "a vibe." He bought a pair of shoes that cost half of my mother's monthly salary, and when I'd raised an eyebrow, he'd gotten defensive.

"Everyone has them, Jonas. It's not a big deal. You should get a pair."

"With what money, Kaelo?" I'd asked, my voice sharper than I intended. "From my tutoring? That pays for our textbooks, remember?"

The words hung in the air between us, ugly and true. He looked away, a flicker of shame in his eyes before it was quickly extinguished by annoyance. "I'll pay you back," he muttered, and we both knew it was a lie. Not because he was malicious, but because money in his new world was an abstract concept, a river that flowed endlessly. In my world, it was something you counted, you worried over, you earned in sweaty, exhausting hours.

The real break came with Anais. She was Seb’s cousin, or something equally vague and interconnected. She was beautiful in the way a marble statue is beautiful: flawless, pale, and cold. She had long, dark hair and eyes the colour of sea glass. She looked at Kaelo like he was a prize she had just won at a fair. And Kaelo, my Kaelo, who had always been so discerning, so grounded despite his flights of fancy, was utterly besotted.

He brought her to the house for Sunday lunch. My mother, ever gracious, prepared a feast. Ndengu, chapati, sukuma wiki, a whole roasted chicken. Anais picked at her food, pushing a single grain of rice around her plate with her fork.

"It's all very... rustic," she said to Kaelo, loud enough for all of us to hear.

My mother’s smile tightened at the edges. My stepfather, David, cleared his throat, his cheerful demeanor faltering for the first time. I felt a hot surge of anger. I wanted to tell her that this "rustic" food was what fueled the boy she was clinging to, that my mother had woken up at dawn to make it perfect. But I looked at Kaelo, and the anger turned to ash in my mouth. He was looking at Anais with an expression of pure adoration, completely oblivious to the insult, to the tension crackling in the room. He reached out and squeezed her hand. "Anais is a bit of a picky eater," he explained to us, as if we were the ones who needed to understand.

After that, he stopped coming home most nights. He was at Anais's flat in Westlands, a sterile, glass-walled apartment with a view of the city I could only dream of. The room we shared became just my room. His side of the closet emptied out, piece by piece. His scent faded from his pillow. The silence was no longer an intruder; it was a permanent resident. The house grew quiet. My mother and David stopped pretending. Their conversations became hushed, worried. They looked at me with pity, and I hated it. I was a living reminder of the son they were losing.

The last time I saw him, the last real time, was six months ago. He'd come by to pick up the last of his things. He looked different. Thinner. His clothes were more expensive, but they hung on him wrong. There were faint, purple smudges under his eyes. Anais was waiting for him outside in a sleek, black Mercedes, honking the horn impatiently.

He was stuffing a few old t-shirts into a duffel bag, avoiding my eyes. The room was thick with unspoken words.

"So, this is it?" I finally asked, my voice barely a whisper.

He stopped, his back to me. "I guess. Look, Jona, I'll still be around."

"Will you?" I laughed, a bitter, broken sound. "You haven't been 'around' in months, Kaelo. You live in a different city. A city that just happens to be a twenty-minute drive away."

He finally turned to face me. The old spark, the Kaelo I knew, was gone from his eyes. They were guarded, tired. "It's not like that."

"What is it like, then? Help me understand. Because from where I'm standing, you traded us. You traded this whole life for... for them. For her."

"You don't understand," he said, his voice rising. "They get it. They get me. Anais… she sees who I can be. Not just... this." He gestured vaguely around the room, at the worn posters on the wall, the堆 of books, the shared history. He had dismissed our entire world with a wave of his hand.

And that's when I broke. "And what was this, Kaelo? What were we? Was it nothing? All those years, was it all just a placeholder until something better came along?"

"Of course not!" he shouted, and for a second, I saw a flicker of the boy who was terrified of moths. "Jonas, you're my brother."

"I'm not your brother!" The words ripped out of my throat, raw and bleeding. "I have never, not for one single day, felt like your brother."

The confession hung in the air, vibrating with all the years of repressed longing. His face changed. The anger drained away, replaced by a stunned, dawning comprehension. He looked at me, really looked at me, and I saw the recognition in his eyes. He knew. Maybe he had always known. The space between us was suddenly charged with a different kind of energy, something fragile and terrifying and years too late.

"Jona..." he started, his voice soft, full of a strange new emotion.

The horn blared from outside, a harsh, ugly sound that shattered the moment. Anais. The spell was broken. Kaelo flinched, looking towards the window. He was a dog on a leash, and his master was calling. He zipped up the duffel bag, the sound unnaturally loud in the quiet room.

"I have to go," he said, his voice flat. He wouldn't look at me again. He walked out of the room, out of the house, and out of my life. I stood there, listening to the crunch of gravel as the Mercedes pulled away. The silence he left behind was absolute.

I sank onto my bed, my body trembling. The photograph on my desk caught my eye. Naivasha. The sun, the grass, his arm around me. A better time. A time before Seb and Anais and the slow, painful amputation of our lives. I clutched the photograph so tightly the corners dug into my palm. A desperate, impossible wish formed in my mind, a prayer to a god I didn't believe in. *Take me back. Just let me go back. Let me fix it. Let me go back to that day.*

And the room began to dissolve. It wasn't a violent change, but a slow, syrupy bleed at the edges of my vision. The barking of the neighbour's dog faded, replaced by the distant cry of a fish eagle. The smell of rain and mud was overwhelmed by the scent of damp earth and acacia blossoms. The gray light of my room brightened, warmed, becoming the golden, late-afternoon sun of the Great Rift Valley. My knuckles were white around the photograph, and the cheap plaster wall in front of me shimmered and reformed itself into a vast, shimmering expanse of water. The world pixelated, fractured, and then snapped into focus.

I was sitting on scratchy grass. The air was warm. A heavy arm was thrown around my shoulder.

"You're a million miles away," a voice said, right beside my ear. A voice I thought I'd only ever hear in my memory again. "What are you thinking about so hard, Jona? You'll sprain your brain."

I turned my head, slowly, my heart a frantic drum against my ribs. He was there. Kaelo. Grinning at me, his eyes clear and bright and full of nothing but easy affection. The tiny gap between his front teeth seemed like the most beautiful imperfection in the universe. He was real. He was here. It was two years ago. The sun was warm on my skin, the photograph wasn't in my hand, and the world was whole again. It had worked. The impossible wish had been granted. I was back.My breath hitched, a painful, sharp thing. It wasn't a memory. The weight of his arm was real, solid, a warm, living pressure across my shoulders. The scent of him wasn't a phantom in a lonely room; it was lake water, sunshine, and the faint, cheap soap from the guesthouse bathroom. I could feel the individual blades of grass pricking the back of my legs. For a dizzying second, the two realities warred in my head – the grey, rain-soaked room and this impossible, sun-drenched gold. But the gold was winning. It was real.

A sob tried to tear its way out of my chest, but I swallowed it down, turning it into a choked gasp. I reached up, my hand trembling, and my fingers brushed against his arm, just to be sure. The skin was warm, the muscles beneath it firm. He was solid. He was here. He was whole. The relief that flooded me was so immense, so tidal, it threatened to drown me. I felt tears prick the corners of my eyes, blurring his beloved, familiar face. Kaelo’s grin faltered, replaced by a flicker of concern.

"Whoa, Jona, you okay? You look like you've seen a ghost." He leaned closer, his dark eyes searching mine. The nearness of him, the genuine worry in his expression, was an agony of sweetness. This was the Kaelo I had lost, the one who could read my silences better than anyone. Before the parties, before the money, before he had learned to look through me.

"No," I managed, my voice a raw whisper. "The opposite of a ghost." I gave a shaky, wet-sounding laugh. "Just… it's beautiful here. I think I got overwhelmed." It was a flimsy excuse, but it was the only one I had. I couldn't possibly tell him the truth. *I just came from the future, a future where you destroy us.* I took a deep, shuddering breath, trying to anchor myself in the here and now. The scent of acacia, the warmth of his body, the sound of water lapping against the shore. These were my anchors now.

Kaelo bought it. Or at least, he accepted my explanation because it was easier than probing the strange, sudden depth of emotion in my eyes. He relaxed, his grin returning. "Overwhelmed by grass? My man, you really are a poet." He squeezed my shoulder, a gesture of casual, uncomplicated affection that made my heart ache. "Come on, let's go skip some stones. I bet I can get one all the way to that patch of reeds." He was already scrambling to his feet, pulling me up with him. His hand in mine was calloused and strong.

As we walked towards the water's edge, I felt a new resolve hardening inside me, like cooling steel. This wasn't a dream. This was a second chance. A terrible, beautiful, impossible second chance. The photograph in my old life, the one I had clutched like a holy relic, wasn't a memory anymore. It was a starting point. The fault line hadn't appeared yet. The ground was firm beneath my feet. Anais didn't exist. Seb was just some unknown boy in a future I now had the power to rewrite. Kaelo was still mine. He was my brother, my friend, the keeper of my secrets. And this time, I would not let him go.

He found a perfect flat stone and, with a fluid motion that was pure Kaelo, sent it skittering across the lake’s surface. It bounced seven times before sinking. He let out a whoop of triumph, turning to me with that sun-splitting grin. "Beat that, my brother!" he challenged, his eyes sparkling with life. I looked at him, truly looked at him, and saw not just the boy beside me, but the man I had lost. The ghost I had been mourning was standing right here, vibrant and alive, his future an unwritten page. And I, the quiet tutor, the secret keeper, would be the one to edit the story. This time, there would be a different ending. I would make sure of it. I would save him from them. I would save him for me.The stone was cool and smooth in my palm, a small, solid piece of the present. I searched for the right words, the right expression, a mask of normalcy to cover the seismic shift that had just occurred within me. I found a faint smile, a shadow of the one he was offering me. "You're on," I said, my voice steadier than I felt. It was the first lie of my new life. The first of many, I suspected. I mimicked his stance, wound my arm back, and flicked my wrist. The stone skipped twice, a pathetic effort, and sank with a quiet 'plop'. Kaelo howled with laughter, a full-throated, joyous sound that echoed across the water. It was a sound I hadn't heard in its pure form for years, unburdened by disappointment or the need to perform for a new, sophisticated audience. I didn't care about the stone; I only cared about that laugh. I wanted to bottle it, to hoard it, to make sure it never faded again.

We spent the next hour in that simple, childish competition. I was clumsy, my mind a turbulent sea of past and future, my movements jerky and uncoordinated. Kaelo, however, was grace personified. He was in his element, a king in his small, temporary kingdom of dust and water and setting sun. I watched him, cataloguing the details I had forgotten or that the future had eroded. The way he bit his lower lip in concentration, the confident set of his shoulders, the sheer, unadulterated life burning in his eyes. This Kaelo hadn't yet learned to be ashamed of his home. He hadn't yet had his accent subtly mocked or his tastes deemed 'rustic'. He hadn't yet learned the poisonous math of comparing his life to others and finding it wanting. He was still just Kaelo, a boy who moved through the world as if it was a party thrown in his honour. And for now, I was his only guest.

As the sun began to dip towards the serrated peaks of the Aberdares, painting the sky in fiery strokes of orange and purple, we collapsed back onto the grass, exhausted and content. The air grew cooler. A profound peace settled over the landscape, a peace that felt both profound and fragile. I knew this peace was an illusion, a temporary ceasefire in a war I had already seen the end of once. This time, I had to be the general, not the casualty. I had to anticipate every move, fortify every weakness.

"KCSEs are going to be hell," Kaelo said, sighing as he stared up at the vast, colourful sky. "I can’t believe this is our last real break before the final push." His voice was laced with a casual dread, the normal anxiety of any student facing national exams. It was a normal conversation, the kind we had had a thousand times. But for me, every word was a clue, every sigh a data point. The KCSEs. The results slip he would wave in my face. The beginning of the end.

"We'll manage," I said, my voice quiet but firm. I rolled onto my side to face him. He was lying on his back, hands laced behind his head. The dying light caught the sharp line of his jaw. "I'll make sure of it." This was more than a promise to help him study; it was a vow. This time, he wouldn't just scrape through. This time, I would build him a foundation so strong that the casual condescension of a boy like Seb would be meaningless. He would not need their validation because he would have his own. "But what about after, Kaelo? Strathmore... is that what you actually want? Business?"

He shrugged, a gesture that made the muscles in his shoulder shift under his t-shirt. "It's a good degree. Dad says it's where the money is. He wants me to be better than him, you know? Not scrambling for contracts, but sitting in a boardroom." There it was. The motivation. David's hope, his booming, infectious hope, was also a pressure, a path laid out for Kaelo that he felt obliged to follow. It was a path that led directly to the Karen set, to the social circles where business deals were made over polo and whiskey.

"There are other ways to make money," I said carefully, testing the waters. "Ways to be 'better'. You're good with people, Kaelo. Not just making friends, but… understanding them. You ever think about something like marketing? Or starting your own thing? Something small, something that's just yours?" I was planting seeds, tiny ideas that might, with enough water and light, grow into a different future. A future where his success wasn't defined by others, in a world that would inevitably reject me.

He turned his head and looked at me, a genuinely curious expression on his face. "My own thing? Like what? Selling roasted maize by the roadside?" he joked, using the same line he would use in two years, but this time it was light, without the weight of a future I knew. I smiled, a real smile this time. "No. Something better. We've got time to think about it. We've got loads of time." For the first time since my dizzying return, I felt a surge of real, unadulterated hope. The path wasn't set in stone. He was listening. He was still listening to me.

The first star pricked the deep indigo of the twilight sky. Kaelo's attention was back on the heavens, his earlier seriousness forgotten. "Look, Jona. A shooting star. Make a wish." He was still a boy who believed in wishes. I didn't need to. Mine had already been granted, a terrifying, cosmic miracle. I looked not at the sky, but at his profile, illuminated by the last vestiges of daylight. I didn't wish for anything. I made a promise. This Kaelo, the one who saw magic in the sky and a future full of vague, hopeful possibilities, was the one I would protect. The fractures that would break him, break us, were still just hairline cracks. And this time, I knew exactly where they were. I was the secret keeper. But now, I would be the gatekeeper, too.The journey back from Naivasha was a silent film played out against the rattling frame of the old Nissan matatu. Kaelo slept, his head lolling onto my shoulder, his breathing a soft, steady rhythm against my ear. In the future I’d left behind, I would have savoured this accidental intimacy, my own body rigid with a desperate, unspoken longing. Now, it was different. I was a watchman on high alert, and his closeness was a responsibility, a weight of a different kind. I watched the blur of the Kenyan countryside—the acacia trees, the small towns with their brightly painted storefronts, the children waving from the roadside—and it all felt sharper, more precious. This was the world I was fighting for. This was the tapestry I had to stop from unravelling.

Returning to our room in South C was the first real test. I stood in the doorway, my bag slung over my shoulder, and looked at the space that had become my prison. The two beds, the shared desk piled high with textbooks, the worn poster of a rally car Kaelo had taped to the wall. It all looked exactly the same, but my perception of it had been fundamentally altered. This was no longer a monument to loss; it was a command centre. His side of the room, which I had last seen as a hollowed-out shell of his absence, was now vibrant with his presence. A crumpled rugby jersey on the floor, the lingering scent of his soap, a dog-eared novel I had recommended to him. The chasm between our beds had vanished. It was just a narrow strip of floor again, easily crossed.

The campaign began that night. The dread of the KCSEs was Kaelo's primary concern, and that was my opening. In the old timeline, I had simply drilled him, forcing facts and formulas into his head through sheer repetition. My goal had been singular: get him the grades his father wanted. It was an act of service, the homework fixer doing his job. This time, I had to be a teacher, not a tutor. I had to make him think, not just memorise. I pulled out the business studies syllabus, a subject he usually groaned about.

"Forget just revising," I said, my tone deliberately casual as we sat at the desk, the single lamp casting a warm circle of light around us. "Let's do something different. Let's make a real business plan. A proper one. For that idea you had, the small one that's just yours." I was echoing my own words from the lakeside, reinforcing the seed I had planted. He looked at me, his brow furrowed. "What idea? Selling maize?" he asked, a hint of his usual deflection in his voice. "No. Think, Kaelo. What are you good at? People. You collect them, remember? You're a brand. 'Kaelo'. Let's build a business around that. A small events company. Or a customised tour guide thing for people who want to see the real Nairobi, not just the tourist traps. We can use the syllabus as a guide—market research, startup costs, branding."

A flicker of interest sparked in his eyes, supplanting the familiar exam weariness. This wasn't about abstract economic theories anymore; it was about him. It was a game, a puzzle, and he was the main character. For the next two hours, he was more engaged than I had ever seen him. He scribbled ideas on a fresh page of his notebook, his handwriting a chaotic scrawl of enthusiasm. He talked about creating unique party experiences, about connecting local artists with small venues, about organising hiking trips to the Ngong Hills. He was alive with a kind of creative energy I had never thought to tap into before. I was no longer just his saviour from academic failure; I was the architect of his potential. I felt a dizzying sense of power, both terrifying and exhilarating.

Our parents were oblivious, caught up in their own bubble of domestic bliss. My mother, Wanjiru, hummed in the kitchen, the scent of her cooking a comforting blanket over the house. David was perpetually optimistic, his booming laugh the house's primary soundtrack. At dinner that Sunday, the four of us crowded around the small dining table, the scene was so painfully normal it felt like a dream. David, serving himself a mountain of ugali, clapped Kaelo on the back. "Soon you'll be at Strathmore, my boy. Eating in the fancy cafeteria, talking big business ideas. Just like we planned." David’s smile was wide, full of pride and unwavering belief in this one specific future.

I saw Kaelo’s own smile falter for a fraction of a second before he caught himself. He glanced at me, a quick, uncertain look. In the old timeline, he would have just grinned and nodded, accepting the praise and the path it laid out. But now, a seed of another idea was sprouting. "Yeah, Dad," he said, his voice lacking its usual conviction. "Maybe." David didn't notice the hesitation, but I did. It was a tiny crack in the foundation of his expectations, and I knew I had to wedge it wider. "Kaelo's been coming up with some of his own business ideas," I interjected smoothly, earning a sharp, warning look from Kaelo that I ignored. "He's got a real mind for marketing."

My mother looked intrigued. "Oh? Like what?" she asked, her kind eyes resting on Kaelo. Kaelo, put on the spot, flushed. "It's nothing, just… Jonas's idea for revision. Some stuff about… events," he mumbled, suddenly shy. But David laughed, a sound that was meant to be encouraging but landed like a dismissal. "That's good, that's good! Get the mind working. You'll need that energy for your corporate strategy classes. The real world is about boardrooms and balance sheets, not parties." The conversation moved on, but the moment hung in the air for me. I had met my primary obstacle. It wasn't a villain; it was a father's love, a father's dream. And it was more powerful than any enemy.

Later that night, the space between our beds felt charged again, but not with distance. It hummed with conspiracy. "Why did you say that to Dad?" Kaelo whispered in the dark. The streetlights cast long shadows across the room. "He thinks my ideas are a joke." I could hear the hurt in his voice, the sting of his father's casual dismissal. "He doesn't think they're a joke," I whispered back, choosing my words with the care of a bomb disposal expert. "He just has a different picture in his head. A picture he's had for a long time. It's hard for people to see a new picture when they love the old one so much."

I sat up, looking over at the shape of him in his bed. "But it doesn't matter what he thinks right now. It's your life, Kaelo. Your future. The business plan… it's not just for revision anymore, is it?" He was silent for a long moment. I could almost hear the gears turning in his head, weighing his father's dream against a new, fragile one of his own. "No," he said finally, his voice soft but clear in the darkness. "I think… I think it could be real." A wave of triumph washed over me, so potent I felt light-headed. This was progress. This was a deviation from the script. I had made him see a different door, and he was considering opening it. I had to keep him here, in this room, dreaming with me, where the temptations of a richer, colder world couldn't reach him. This time, I would be his brightest flame.The months leading up to the KCSEs transformed our room into a command centre, a war room for a battle fought on two fronts. The first was against calculus and the complex history of the East African Protectorate. The second, my secret war, was for Kaelo’s soul. Our shared desk disappeared under a blizzard of papers: my neat, colour-coded revision notes lay alongside Kaelo’s sprawling, chaotic mind-maps. We didn’t just revise; we strategized. I reframed every subject through the lens of the nascent business plan we had christened ‘Nairobi Unlocked’. Economics wasn’t just theory; it was the blueprint for our startup costs. English wasn’t just literature; it was crafting the perfect pitch to a potential client. For the first time, Kaelo wasn’t just studying to pass; he was studying to build. He would pace the small room, energized and full of ideas, using a ruler as a prop while he practiced a presentation for an imaginary investor, his only audience me, sitting on my bed, playing the role of stern-faced banker.

Our friendship, which had been fading into silence in the other life, found its voice again in these late-night sessions. The silence was filled not with the ghosts of unspoken feelings, but with shared purpose. We laughed more than we had in years, the sound rich and easy in the small room. Kaelo’s charisma, which I had once watched with a kind of detached admiration, was now a tool I was helping him sharpen. He was the frontman, the visionary, the heart of Nairobi Unlocked. I was the strategist, the logistician, the one who made sure the beautiful, chaotic ideas could actually work. We were a team, a closed circuit of energy and ambition. The world outside our room, with its barking dogs and muddy lanes, ceased to matter. We were building our own world on sheets of foolscap paper, a world where he was the star and I was his indispensable right hand.

The first test of Nairobi Unlocked came in the form of the ‘Post-KCSE Blowout Bash’, Kaelo’s name for it. In the past, this would have been an aimless gathering in someone’s backyard. He zipped the bag shut, the sound echoing in the funereal silence. He slung it over his shoulder and walked towards the door, his movements stiff, his back a rigid wall of unforgiveness. He paused at the doorway but didn't turn around. "Where are you going?" I asked, my voice a ragged whisper, clinging to the last, impossible sliver of hope that this could be undone. "No," he said finally, the single word heavier than a tombstone. "Away from you, Jonas. Away from this room. Away from the lie you built and tried to call a life." He stepped out of the doorway and was gone. I listened to his footsteps, firm and resolute, fading down the hall, followed by the soft click of the front door. The silence he left behind was no longer a temporary state. It was a verdict. It was absolute. I sank onto my bed, my body trembling, my vision blurring. A few days later, a single text message from Kaelo to his father provided the official narrative. He had not chosen her. He had chosen himself, by rejecting me.

The rain began to fall that evening, a familiar, drumming sound against the corrugated iron roof of the neighbour's extension. But it was no longer a sound from a past I couldn't seem to escape. The past was a closed book, a failed experiment. This rain was the sound of the present, a bleak, endless, and self-inflicted exile. I stood at the single window, looking out at the muddy lane, at the perpetually barking dog, at the world I had fought so desperately to preserve. I had won, in the most pyrrhic way imaginable. He had left me in the first life, but I had still owned his memory, his ghost. Now, he was out there in the world, alive and whole, and his memory of me was one of betrayal. I had not saved him. I had simply become the monster he needed to escape.A week passed, then two. The house settled into a new, brittle rhythm, the rhythm of a ceasefire in a war where everyone had lost. Meals were silent, functional affairs. David would eat quickly, his gaze fixed on his plate, his presence a black hole of anger that absorbed all light and sound. He did not leave, which was its own form of punishment; he remained as a constant, looming monument to my failure. My mother, Wanjiru, moved through the ruins of our home like a ghost, her footsteps too soft, her hands always finding something to wipe or straighten, a futile attempt to impose order on a fundamentally broken world. Her love for David was a visible wound, and my presence was the salt that kept it raw. She loved me, I knew she did, but looking at me was looking at the architect of her pain. And I, in turn, remained in my cell, the door unlocked but impassable, held captive by the geography of my own guilt.

It was my mother who finally breached the perimeter. She appeared at my door one afternoon, a cup of tea in her hands, her face a careful mask of neutrality. She had not entered the room since the day Kaelo left. I watched as her eyes took in the scene: my own unkempt state, the pristine, untouched shrine of Kaelo’s bed, the oppressive weight of the silence. She set the tea on the edge of the desk, her hand moving to push the silver laptop a few inches away, a small, unconscious gesture of distaste. She did not sit on his bed, but pulled the desk chair around to face me, creating a small, formal island of engagement in the vast ocean of our misery.

“Jonas,” she began, her voice low and steady, the voice she used for difficult things. “David has not spoken your name in sixteen days. I hear him walking the floors at night. This house… our home… it is dying.” She looked at me, her gaze not accusatory, but deeply, profoundly weary. It was a mother’s exhaustion, a sorrow that went beyond the immediate drama and saw the long, bleak road of unhappiness stretching out before all of us. “I do not know everything that was said in this room. But I know it was not just about a business or new friends. I am your mother. I have watched you watch him for years. Do not let this silence be the thing that buries us all.”

Her words, gentle but firm, were the key I could not turn for myself. I looked at her, at the lines of worry carved around her mouth, lines I had put there, and the dam of my self-imposed silence broke. I did not tell her about Naivasha, about the impossible wish, the second chance. The truth was too fantastical, too insane. But I told her the core of it, the truth that had driven both timelines to ruin. I told her that my love for Kaelo was not the love of a brother. I confessed the jealousy I had felt, the terror of being left behind, the desperate, twisting fear that had curdled into a need for control. My voice was a low, cracked monotone as I recounted my manipulations, framing them as a twisted, misguided attempt to keep our small world from breaking apart. I confessed to her my sin: not that I loved him, but that I had tried to own him.

She listened without interruption, her hands clasped in her lap, her expression unreadable. When I finally fell silent, the confession hanging in the stale air like smoke, she did not recoil. She did not offer platitudes or easy forgiveness. She reached out and placed her hand over mine, her skin warm and calloused against my cold knuckles. “Oh, my child,” she whispered, and her voice was thick with a grief that encompassed everything—for Kaelo, for David, for the family that was, but most of all, for me. “Love is not a fortress you build to keep someone in, Jonas. It is a garden you tend, hoping they will want to stay. You cannot force a flower to bloom in the dark because you are afraid of the sun.” She squeezed my hand, a gesture of profound, painful empathy. "You were afraid. I understand fear. But you used your fear to build a cage for him, and for yourself. And now you are both trapped."

Her gaze fell upon the silver laptop, the alien object on the desk. "This," she said, her voice regaining a sliver of its practical strength. "This is not ours. Cleaning up even the smallest piece of the wreckage was an active one.

“How?” I asked, my voice barely audible. “I don’t know where he is. I can’t…” I couldn't say Anais's name. "The girl," my mother said, her voice firm. "This belongs to the girl. Find her. The journey to Strathmore was a pilgrimage into enemy territory, but this time I felt no sense of rebellion, only a profound and hollow sense of otherness. Finding her was a daunting task. I had no plan, no specific location to search. I simply began to walk, a phantom drifting through the streams of students, my plain canvas bag and worn-out shoes a stark contrast to their designer backpacks and fashionable attire. I felt the casual, uninterested glances of people passing by, the same dismissive gaze I had felt in the Karen café, but now it carried no sting, only a quiet confirmation of my own irrelevance. I watched them, these children of diplomats and politicians, these future CEOs and power brokers. They laughed and flirted and debated lecture points, their lives a seamless continuation of the privilege they had been born into. I searched their faces for a sign of Kaelo, a flash of his familiar grin or confident stride, but he was not there. The campus felt emptier for his absence, a stage without its star.

I saw her before she saw me. She was seated at an outdoor table at the campus bistro, the epicenter of a small, rapt audience. She held a cup of coffee in one hand, gesturing with the other as she spoke, her expression animated and intelligent. Even from a distance, her charisma was a tangible force, a low-frequency hum of competence and control. She was in her element, a queen holding court. I stood up, slung the bag more firmly onto my shoulder, and began the long walk across the manicured lawn towards her table.

As I approached, the hum of their conversation faltered, one by one her companions noticing the intruder in their midst. Anais followed their gazes and her eyes met mine. There was a flicker of surprise, quickly masked by a cool, unreadable composure. She did not smile. She simply watched me come, her stillness a form of power. I stopped at the edge of her table, the scent of her perfume a faint, jarring memory. I did not offer a greeting. I unslung the canvas bag, reached inside, and placed the silver laptop on the table between us. The metallic sound it made as it connected with the glass surface was the only sound in the sudden, complete silence. "I came to return this," I said, my voice flat, devoid of emotion. "It's yours."

Her eyes, the colour of sea glass, held mine for a long moment, searching, analyzing. She was not just seeing me; she was reading me, assessing the depth of my defeat. With a subtle, almost imperceptible nod, she dismissed the others at her table. They gathered their things with a quiet efficiency, casting curious, speculative glances at me as they left, until it was just the two of us, separated by the gleaming symbol of our failed triangular war. It was the question I had been dreading, the one that stripped away the last of my defenses. The truth was my only remaining currency, and it was bankrupt. "He isn't with you?" The question was a genuine, desperate inquiry, the first I had asked that was not part of a strategy, and she knew it. The cool composure of her expression finally fractured, replaced by a flicker of genuine surprise, and then a sliver of something else: annoyance. The strategist had encountered an unexpected variable that had disrupted her own meticulous plans.

"No," she said, her voice losing some of its melodic calm, becoming sharper, more clipped. "He isn't with me. He sent me a single, solitary text message two weeks ago saying he needed space to think. "He left," I said, the simple statement a final confession for us both. "He said he was leaving me. I thought that meant he was coming to you." A bitter, ironic smile touched my lips. "It seems he left us both." Anais stared at the laptop, her long fingers drumming a soft, irritated rhythm against its surface. She was no longer looking at me, but at the wreckage of her own ambitions. She had seen Kaelo as a brilliant, raw asset to be molded and directed. I had seen him as a precious treasure to be guarded and protected. We had both been wrong. He was not an asset or a treasure. He was a man, and he had finally, explosively, chosen to belong to no one but himself. The silence between us was no longer a battlefield; it was a shared, empty space, the quiet aftermath of a storm that had swept away everything.

Without another word, I turned and walked away. I did not look back. I could feel her eyes on my back, but I no longer cared what she was thinking. My mission, my penance, was complete. We had both lost him, to his own desperate, necessary bid for freedom. The journey home was quiet, but the emptiness inside me felt different now. It was not the agonizing void of guilt. It was a clean, desolate, and strangely peaceful emptiness. It was the silence of ground zero.When I walked back into the house, the silence felt different. It was still heavy, but the suffocating quality of stale guilt had been replaced by a clean, sharp emptiness. The spell of paralysis that had held our home captive had been broken by a single, small act of motion.

David came home an hour later. He walked into the living room, his face set in the same rigid lines of anger it had worn for weeks. But before he could retreat into the frozen silence of his room, my mother spoke, her voice calm and clear. “Jonas returned the laptop today,” she said, not looking up from her sewing. “He went to the university. He stood there for a long, silent moment, processing, before continuing on to his room without a word. But his retreat felt different. It was no longer the slam of a locked door, but the quiet click of one being left slightly ajar.

Later that evening, as I was clearing the plates from our silent dinner, my mother stopped me in the kitchen. “And Kaelo?” she asked, her voice barely a whisper, freighted with the hope she had been too afraid to voice earlier. The brief peace I had found at ground zero shattered. I had returned from my mission with a casualty report, and now it was time to deliver it. I turned to face her, the last of my defenses gone. “He isn’t with her,” I said, the words stark and bare. “She said he sent her a message. That he needed space. She thought he was here. I watched it land, watched the hope in her eyes extinguish, replaced by a raw, maternal terror that was a thousand times worse than anger or disappointment. I was not just the cause of the fight; I was the reason for this new, unbearable terror. The next day, I began to reclaim my space. I started with Kaelo’s bed. Then I opened his drawers and began to pack away the few things he had left behind: a worn rugby jersey, a handful of mismatched socks, a dog-eared paperback I had lent him years ago. The house remained a place of quiet grief, but the sharp edges of animosity began to dull, worn down by the shared, overriding anxiety for Kaelo’s safety. Seeing his raw, paternal pain, I felt a strange and terrible empathy for him. The real test came not from within the house, but from the outside world, an email that landed in my inbox like a message from a ghost. He had run from everyone who had a plan for him, everyone who saw him as an asset, a prize, a project, or a son they needed to be proud of. He had run from love that had started to feel like ownership. To respect him, to truly love him now, meant accepting his decision. It meant letting him go.

I walked back to my room, leaving them to their debate. I sat at my desk and opened my laptop, the blank email from the historian staring back at me. I looked at the Nairobi Unlocked notebooks, at the record of a good idea, a shared dream. Kaelo was gone, but the dream wasn't. It was here, on my desk. It was mine now, not through theft or conquest, but through abandonment. I took a deep breath, the first truly deep breath I had taken in months, and began to type. *Thank you for your email,* I wrote. *My partner is unavailable for the foreseeable future, but I would be honored to show your colleague the city.* I paused, my finger hovering over the keyboard, before typing the final, terrifying, liberating words. *Jonas Mwangi, Nairobi Unlocked.* I hit send before I could lose my nerve. I wasn't chasing a ghost. I was finally, quietly, stepping into my own life.Hitting 'send' on the email was like stepping off a cliff in the dark. For a terrifying, breathless moment, there was only the fall, the sickening lurch of a future now irrevocably in motion. Then, my feet found solid ground. It was not the ground I had left, but it was solid nonetheless. In the living room, the frantic, circular argument between David and Wanjiru continued its painful orbit, a storm of fear and recrimination I was no longer a part of. I quietly closed my bedroom door, the soft click a declaration of intent. Their war was to find Kaelo, to reclaim the past. My task was to survive the present. I sat at my desk, the silence of my room a stark contrast to the chaos outside, and felt a profound, unnerving, and utterly unfamiliar sense of peace. I had let go. I had no idea what would happen next, and for the first time in either of my lives, that felt less like a terror and more like a possibility.

Dr. Alistair Finch replied two days later. The email was brief, professional, and blessedly devoid of sentiment. He was interested. The dates were confirmed. It was real. A wave of pure, undiluted panic washed over me, so intense it almost sent me running back to the safety of my guilt. How could I possibly do this? Kaelo was the sun, the voice, the lifeblood of Nairobi Unlocked. I was the nervous system, the quiet, invisible infrastructure. How could a nervous system walk and talk and lead a tour? I pulled out the old notebooks, my hands trembling slightly. Kaelo’s bold, looping handwriting seemed to mock me from the page. His notes were a collection of names, jokes, connections, moments of pure, unadulterated charisma. I couldn’t replicate them. I couldn’t perform Kaelo. The thought of trying, of failing to capture his specific magic, was humiliating. I would be a ghost haunting his own creation, a pale imitation that only highlighted the brilliance of the original.

For a full day, I was paralyzed. Then, my mother’s words came back to me: *Love is not a fortress you build to keep someone in*. I had spent years trying to be the anchor, the strategist, the fixer, the one who made Kaelo’s world possible. But I had never stopped to ask what my own world looked like. I took out a fresh notebook, my own notebook, and placed it beside the old ones. I began to build a new tour, my tour. I used our old routes as a skeleton, but I began to add my own flesh. Where Kaelo had noted the name of a friendly trader who told good stories, I researched the history of that specific trade route, the colonial policies that had shaped the marketplace. Where Kaelo had a joke about a local politician, I added a paragraph about the evolution of grassroots political movements in Nairobi’s informal settlements. The tour shifted from a performance of charm to a narrative of history, from a collection of anecdotes to a deep, contextualized reading of the city’s soul. I was not a storyteller. I was an urban archaeologist, and the city was my dig site.

David left for Nakuru on a Tuesday morning. He did not ask me to come, and he and my mother had a final, quiet, tense exchange at the door. He drove off in a cloud of desperate hope and simmering anger, leaving a fragile truce in his wake. Wanjiru and I were left behind, the sole occupants of a house that felt both vast and claustrophobic. That afternoon, she came into my room and saw the new notes spread across my desk, the maps, the historical texts borrowed from the library. She looked at my meticulous handwriting, so different from Kaelo’s, and her expression softened. “You are preparing,” she said, not as a question, but as a quiet observation. I nodded. “I have a client. A historian.” She placed a hand on my shoulder, a brief, warm pressure. “That is good, Jonas,” she said. “It is good to work.” In her eyes, I saw not just approval, but a flicker of hope for me, a hope that was separate from the all-consuming terror she felt for her other son.

Dr. Finch was a tall, stooped man in his late sixties, with a kind, weary face and eyes that held the patient, observant gaze of a lifelong academic. He wore a practical sun hat and carried a small, leather-bound notebook. When we met outside the national archives, he shook my hand with a dry, firm grip and a polite, reserved smile. There was no expectation of charm, no demand for entertainment. He was here to learn. This quiet, serious man was the perfect first passenger for my maiden voyage. My initial nervousness, a frantic beat in my throat, began to subside. He was not looking for a performance. He was looking for a colleague.

The tour began stiffly. My voice was tight as I recited the carefully rehearsed history of the city’s founding. But as we moved from the sterile city centre into the living, breathing chaos of the River Road district, the city itself began to take over. It was in the back alleys, navigating the throng of people selling everything from cheap electronics to herbal remedies, that my fear finally broke. We were standing near a building whose colonial-era facade was crumbling, revealing the older brickwork beneath. Dr. Finch, instead of asking a general question, pointed to a specific joint in the brickwork. “Flemish bond,” he murmured, more to himself than to me. “Unusual for a building of this period here. I wonder who the masons were.” Kaelo would have laughed and made a joke about old buildings having their secrets. But the question lit a fire in my brain. “They were likely Goan,” I said, my voice suddenly finding its footing. “There was a large community of skilled Goan stonemasons brought in to work on the railway. Their influence is all over the early city architecture, but it’s often overlooked in the official histories, which focus on the British engineers.”

That was the key. Dr. Finch didn't want the big picture; he wanted the footnotes, the marginalia, the hidden stories I had spent my life quietly collecting. The rest of the tour became a dialogue. We stood in the cacophony of Gikomba market, and I found myself not telling jokes, but explaining the complex, informal banking systems that allowed the traders to thrive outside of formal institutions. We walked through a quiet residential street, and I pointed out the subtle architectural shifts that told the story of the changing racial zoning laws under colonial rule. I was not performing Nairobi; I was deconstructing it, piece by piece, for an audience of one who understood the value of every shard. Ghosts of Kaelo followed me, moments where I knew he would have charmed a shopkeeper into giving us a free sample or broken the ice with a group of laughing children. I acknowledged them, a quiet ache in my chest, but I did not let them silence me. I was not him. My gift was not connection, but context. And for the first time, I realized that context had its own quiet, powerful magic.

At the end of the day, we sat at a small, unassuming café, the same kind of place I would have taken Kaelo. Dr. Finch was slowly flipping through the notes he had taken in his leather-bound book. “Remarkable,” he said, finally looking up at me. “Truly remarkable. I’ve had guides all over the world, Mr. Mwangi. Most of them show you the sights. You have shown me the city’s bones.” He reached into his wallet and paid me, adding a generous tip that made me flush with a pride that was sharp and new and entirely my own. This was money I had earned not as a fixer, not as a background player, but as myself. As Jonas Mwangi, Nairobi Unlocked. I walked home through the gathering dusk, the city streets alive with the evening rush. I was exhausted, my throat hoarse from talking, but I felt a lightness I hadn’t experienced in years. I had stepped out from behind the curtain and found not a hostile, jeering audience, but a single, appreciative soul who had seen me, the real me, and had deemed me worthy. It was not a victory. It was not a cure. But it was a beginning. My beginning.The fragile peace I had carved out for myself was a house of cards, and the sound of David’s car pulling into the drive was the tremor that threatened to bring it all down. For three days, a quiet, functional truce had held between my mother and me. We were two survivors on a deserted island, tending to the small necessities of existence while the vast, silent ocean of David’s absence stretched around us. I had thrown myself into my work, burying my anxiety under layers of historical research, building the itinerary for Dr. Finch’s tour into a fortress of facts and figures. It was a flimsy defense, but it was all I had. Now, the expedition was over. The search party was returning, and we had no idea if he was coming back with a rescued son or a death certificate for our hope.

My mother and I met in the hallway without a word, drawn from our separate rooms by the sound of the engine cutting out. We stood there, a silent, two-person honour guard, waiting for the verdict. The car door slammed, a sound of finality, not triumph. Then the front door opened, and David walked in. He was a man hollowed out from the inside. The anger that had been his armour for weeks was gone, leaving him exposed and brittle. His face was a grey mask of road dust and despair, his shoulders slumped not with weariness, but with the profound, crushing weight of defeat. He carried a small overnight bag that seemed impossibly heavy in his hand. He looked at us, his eyes passing over me and settling on my mother, and in their depths was a grief so absolute it was terrifying.

"He is alive," David said, his voice a rough, cracked whisper, as if he hadn't used it for days. The words were meant to be a comfort, but they landed with the thud of a closing coffin lid. Wanjiru let out a small, strangled sob, a sound of both relief and terror. David walked past us into the living room and sank into his armchair, the springs groaning in protest. He dropped the bag by his feet and stared at the opposite wall, his gaze unfocused, seeing not the familiar room but a dusty petrol station in a forgotten town. My mother followed him, her hand hovering near his shoulder, afraid to offer a comfort that might shatter him completely.

"I found him," David began, his voice a monotone recital of a nightmare. "It was him. The boy was right. He was at the petrol station. Thinner. His head shaved. He was wearing overalls, cleaning a windshield. I got out of the car and I called his name. He didn't turn around. I had to walk right up to him, stand in front of him. Jonas… he looked at me." He finally turned his head and looked at me, his gaze direct for the first time in a month. The anger was gone, replaced by a terrible, shared understanding. "He looked at me like he'd never seen me before in his life. Just a blankness. A total, complete emptiness."

My mother knelt by his chair, her hand finally coming to rest on his knee. "What did he say, David? What did my son say?" "I told him I was there to take him home," David continued, his voice breaking. "He just shook his head slowly, as if I were a child who didn't understand. He said, 'This is my home.' I begged him, Wanjiru. I begged. I told him you were sick with worry. I tried to give him money, all the cash I had. I told him he could have anything, a new car, his own flat, anything he wanted." A single tear traced a path through the dust on David’s cheek. He looked down at his own hands, large, capable hands that had built a business and provided for a family, and saw only their uselessness. "He looked at the money in my hand. Then he looked at me. And he smiled, a little, sad smile. 'It’s too late for that, Dad,' he said. 'You can't buy me back.' Then he just picked up his rag and cloth and walked to the next car. He didn't even look back as I drove away."

The story hung in the air, a devastatingly simple epitaph for a life. He hadn't just run from me. He hadn't run to Anais. He had run from the entire concept of being owned, of being a project, of being an investment whose returns were measured in pride or love or ambition. He had performed a radical act of self-amputation, cutting away not just the people in his life, but the very identity they had all, in their own ways, tried to shape for him. He had chosen anonymity. He had chosen nothing.

The house fell into a new, more profound silence. It was not the angry silence of recrimination or the anxious silence of waiting. It was the deep, resonant silence of mourning, the quiet that comes after the body has been laid to rest. David did not retreat to his room. He sat in his armchair for hours, staring into space, a king surveying a ruined kingdom. My mother sat with him, her sewing forgotten, her presence a quiet, steadfast vigil. I was an island in their shared grief, the cause of the shipwreck but no longer its primary focus. Later that evening, as darkness fell, I went to the kitchen and poured a glass of water. On impulse, I poured a second. I walked into the living room and placed the glass on the small table beside David’s chair. He didn't look at me, but as I turned to leave, I heard the soft clink of the glass being lifted from the table. It was the first offering I had made that he had not refused.

I went back to my room and sat at my desk. Kaelo was not missing anymore. He was gone. The distinction was crucial. A missing person leaves a space of frantic, hopeful searching. A gone person leaves a clean, cold, permanent void. The ghost that had haunted me, the possibility of his return, of a confrontation, of a final, terrible scene, was finally laid to rest. The story was over. There was no more to manipulate, no more to fix, no more to fear. There was only the quiet, empty room and the work that lay on my desk. I picked up my pen and looked at the notes for Dr. Finch’s tour, at the meticulous history of a city that had survived fires and plagues and wars, a city that was constantly being torn down and rebuilt. I was no longer a castaway waiting for rescue. I was just a man, like the city I lived in, standing in the ruins of what had been, with the quiet, solitary, and strangely hopeful task of deciding what to build next.The months that followed were not a time of healing, but of scar tissue forming over a wound that would never truly close. The raw, screaming grief in the house subsided, replaced by a low-grade, chronic ache that became the new baseline of their existence. David went back to his contracting work with a grim, relentless energy, burying his despair under a mountain of invoices and site visits. He was a man running on fumes, his booming laugh and easy optimism replaced by a clipped, weary efficiency. He still rarely spoke to me, but the overt animosity had bled away, leaving a shared, exhausted emptiness. We were two soldiers who had survived the same devastating battle, now occupying the same trench out of sheer necessity, the cause of our war a ghost neither of us dared to name. My mother, the quiet, tireless diplomat of our broken nation, continued to tend to the fragile peace, her love a constant, low flame that kept the encroaching darkness from consuming us completely.

My own world shrank and then, slowly, began to expand on its own terms. Dr. Finch’s recommendation proved to be a powerful catalyst. It led to a quiet but steady stream of clients: a Dutch journalist researching urban planning, a graduate student from Berkeley studying post-colonial literature, a retired British couple who wanted to understand the city beyond the sanitized confines of their safari tour. These were not people looking for a party; they were looking for a lecture, and I, for the first time in my life, was the man at the podium. I found my voice not in the boisterous charm I had once so admired in Kaelo, but in the quiet authority of knowledge. I led them through the city’s veins, pointing out the architectural ghosts of past regimes, the linguistic tells in street names, the economic fault lines hidden in plain sight. I was not Kaelo’s charismatic frontman. I was Jonas Mwangi, the urban archaeologist, and my tours were not experiences; they were excavations. The money I earned felt different, heavier, more real than any shilling I had ever counted before. It was the currency of my own competence, earned by my own mind and my own two feet.

One evening, I was spread out on the dining room table, a space I had tentatively reclaimed as my office, cross-referencing a tattered 1950s survey map with a modern satellite image on my phone. The house was quiet, the only sounds the chirping of crickets and the distant hum of the city. David entered the room to get a glass of water, his movements heavy with the day’s fatigue. He paused behind me, his shadow falling across my work. I tensed, expecting him to move on, but he remained. I could feel his eyes on the intricate lines of the old map, the scribbled notes in the margins. "What is all this?" he asked, his voice rough, neutral. It was the first direct, non-essential question he had asked me in three months. I swallowed, my throat suddenly dry. "It's for a tour tomorrow," I explained, my voice just as neutral. "I'm showing a client the original layouts of the segregated housing estates and how their boundaries still influence the city’s informal economy today." He grunted, a noncommittal sound. He took his glass of water and walked towards the hallway, but paused at the door. "Is there a living to be made in old maps, Jonas?" he asked, not unkindly, but with the genuine, pragmatic curiosity of a businessman. The question was a seismic shift. He was not asking about Kaelo’s business; he was asking about mine. "A small one," I said, looking back at my work. "But it's a start." He nodded slowly, a silent acknowledgment, and then disappeared into the darkness of the hall, leaving me with the quiet hum of possibility.

The name ‘Nairobi Unlocked’ had become an ill-fitting suit, a costume from a play I was no longer a part of. It was a name built for two, a name that echoed with a voice that was no longer there. It promised an opening, a revealing, a burst of energy, and my tours were something else entirely. They were quiet, deep, and analytical. I was not unlocking the city; I was reading it. One afternoon, sitting in the familiar hum of the local cybercafé, I opened a simple word processing program and typed my own name at the top of the page. Underneath it, I tried different phrases: ‘Historical Walks’, ‘Urban Deconstructions’, ‘City Context’. They all felt either too pretentious or too dull. Finally, I settled on the simplest, most honest description I could think of. *Jonas Mwangi: Nairobi Historical & Contextual Tours.* It was plain. It was unadorned. It was me. I designed a new flyer, just black text on a clean white background, my phone number and email at the bottom. The act of printing out a stack of these new flyers, their edges sharp and clean, felt like a quiet, deeply personal declaration of independence.

I pinned one of the new flyers to the corkboard in my room, in the space where a faded poster of a rally car had once been taped. The simple black and white design stood out against the chipped plaster, a small flag planted on a new shore. That night, the rain came again, a drumming, frantic heartbeat against the corrugated iron roof. I stood at my window, listening. The sound no longer dragged me back to Naivasha or to the last, terrible fight. It was no longer a frantic heartbeat mimicking the one in my own chest. The memories were still there, like faint, silvery scars under the skin, but they no longer had the power to hijack the present. The past was a country I had emigrated from. I carried its accent and some of its customs, but I no longer lived there. I listened to the downpour, and for the first time in a very long time, it was not the sound of a past I couldn’t escape. It was just rain, washing the dust from the city, and I had work to do in the morning.

parts.text:
The rain against the corrugated iron roof of the neighbour's extension was a sound from a past I couldn't seem to escape. It was a drumming, a frantic heartbeat that mimicked the one in my own chest the last time I saw him. Here, in my small room in South C, with its single window looking out onto a muddy lane and a perpetually barking dog, the past was a more solid presence than the chipped plaster on the walls. It had weight. It had the scent of Kaelo’s cologne, a sharp, citrusy thing he’d saved up for months to buy, and the warmth of his body asleep in the bed next to mine.

Our mothers had decided we would share a room. A pragmatic decision, born of a four-bedroom house that was suddenly too small for two families stitched together. My mother, Wanjiru, and his father, David, were so caught up in the giddy orbit of their new love that they saw no potential for friction, only harmony. “You’ll be brothers,” David had said, clapping us both on the shoulder, his voice booming with a kind of hope that felt both naïve and infectious. And for a long time, he was right. We were more than brothers. Kaelo was the anchor to my drifting boat, the bright, chaotic colour in my monochrome life.

I was the tutor. The quiet one, the reader, the one who navigated the shoals of calculus and chemistry with a grim determination. Kaelo was… Kaelo. He moved through the world as if it was a party thrown in his honour. Laughter trailed him like a cape. He collected friends the way other boys collected bottle caps, effortlessly, amassing a treasure trove of mismatched, loyal people. And I was his first, his most prized. The secret keeper. The homework fixer. The one who knew he was terrified of moths and that he hummed off-key when he thought no one was listening.

The rain fell harder, a silver sheet that blurred the world outside. I picked up the photograph from my desk, its edges softened with handling. It was from two years ago, a trip to Naivasha. We are sitting on the scratchy grass by the lake, Kaelo’s arm thrown around my shoulder, his head tilted towards mine. He is grinning, a wide, sun-splitting thing that shows the tiny gap between his front teeth. I am smiling too, a smaller, more contained version of his joy, but my eyes are fixed only on him. It was a moment of pure, uncomplicated happiness. A time before the fault line appeared, before the ground began to tremble beneath my feet. Before Anais.

It started, as most endings do, with a beginning. Kaelo had just scraped through his KCSEs, a feat he attributed entirely to my nightly drilling sessions. "Jonas, my brother, my saviour," he'd yelled, waving the results slip in the air. "Without you, I'd be selling roasted maize by the roadside!" He'd hugged me, lifting me off the ground in a whirlwind of relief and gratitude. In that moment, pressed against his chest, smelling the sweat and sun on his skin, the feeling that had been a quiet hum in my blood for years crescendoed into a roar. It was love. Not brotherly, not friendly. It was a deep, aching, terrifying love.

He was supposed to be studying business at Strathmore, a concession to his father. But Kaelo treated university like an extension of his social life. The campus was just a new, grander stage. And on that stage, he met them. The Karen set. Children of diplomats and politicians and old money, people who vacationed in Malindi as casually as we took a matatu into town. They drove cars that cost more than our house. They spoke with an accent that was a strange hybrid of British television and inherited entitlement.

The first time he brought one of them home, it was a boy named Seb. Seb had pale, freckled skin and a lazy, assessing gaze that made me feel like an interesting insect. He surveyed our living room, with its mismatched furniture and my mother's vibrant kitenge curtains, with a kind of detached amusement.

"So this is where you live, K," Seb said, drawing out the 'K' into a low drawl. "It's… cozy."

Kaelo, who had never once been ashamed of our home, flushed slightly. "It's home," he said, his voice a little too loud. "Jonas, this is Seb. We're in the same macroeconomics class."

"I'm his tutor, mostly," Seb added with a thin smile, looking at me. "He's a bright lad, just needs to apply himself."

I just nodded, the words sticking in my throat. I was used to being the smart one, the one Kaelo looked up to. But in Seb’s world, I was the help. Kaelo didn’t seem to notice the subtle shift, the re-categorization of my existence. He was too dazzled by Seb’s stories of polo matches and weekends in the Mara. He was a moth drawn to a brighter, more dangerous flame.

That night, the space between our beds in the room we still shared felt like a chasm. Kaelo was buzzing, tapping away on his phone, a small smile playing on his lips.

"Seb's hilarious," he said, not looking at me. "His dad is the ambassador for Sweden or something. They're having a party on Saturday. At their place. You should come, Jona."

"I don't think so," I said, turning to face the wall. "I have papers to mark." It was a lie. My weekend was a blank slate, as always.

"Oh. Okay." He sounded disappointed, but only for a second. The blue light of his phone illuminated his face, casting him in an alien glow. He was already somewhere else, in a world of embassy parties and casual wealth, a world where I had no place. I felt a cold dread seep into my bones. It was the first time he had ever accepted my refusal so easily. Usually, he would wheedle and bargain and tease until I gave in. But not this time. The thread was fraying.

The parties became a regular thing. Saturdays, then Fridays too. He started coming home late, smelling of expensive whiskey and a perfume that wasn't his. He'd stumble into our room, shedding clothes onto the floor, and fall into bed without a word. The late-night talks, the whispered confessions and shared jokes that had been the bedrock of our friendship, vanished. They were replaced by a silence that was louder than any argument. He started using their slang, calling things "peak" and "a vibe." He bought a pair of shoes that cost half of my mother's monthly salary, and when I'd raised an eyebrow, he'd gotten defensive.

"Everyone has them, Jonas. It's not a big deal. You should get a pair."

"With what money, Kaelo?" I'd asked, my voice sharper than I intended. "From my tutoring? That pays for our textbooks, remember?"

The words hung in the air between us, ugly and true. He looked away, a flicker of shame in his eyes before it was quickly extinguished by annoyance. "I'll pay you back," he muttered, and we both knew it was a lie. Not because he was malicious, but because money in his new world was an abstract concept, a river that flowed endlessly. In my world, it was something you counted, you worried over, you earned in sweaty, exhausting hours.

The real break came with Anais. She was Seb’s cousin, or something equally vague and interconnected. She was beautiful in the way a marble statue is beautiful: flawless, pale, and cold. She had long, dark hair and eyes the colour of sea glass. She looked at Kaelo like he was a prize she had just won at a fair. And Kaelo, my Kaelo, who had always been so discerning, so grounded despite his flights of fancy, was utterly besotted.

He brought her to the house for Sunday lunch. My mother, ever gracious, prepared a feast. Ndengu, chapati, sukuma wiki, a whole roasted chicken. Anais picked at her food, pushing a single grain of rice around her plate with her fork.

"It's all very... rustic," she said to Kaelo, loud enough for all of us to hear.

My mother’s smile tightened at the edges. My stepfather, David, cleared his throat, his cheerful demeanor faltering for the first time. I felt a hot surge of anger. I wanted to tell her that this "rustic" food was what fueled the boy she was clinging to, that my mother had woken up at dawn to make it perfect. But I looked at Kaelo, and the anger turned to ash in my mouth. He was looking at Anais with an expression of pure adoration, completely oblivious to the insult, to the tension crackling in the room. He reached out and squeezed her hand. "Anais is a bit of a picky eater," he explained to us, as if we were the ones who needed to understand.

After that, he stopped coming home most nights. He was at Anais's flat in Westlands, a sterile, glass-walled apartment with a view of the city I could only dream of. The room we shared became just my room. His side of the closet emptied out, piece by piece. His scent faded from his pillow. The silence was no longer an intruder; it was a permanent resident. The house grew quiet. My mother and David stopped pretending. Their conversations became hushed, worried. They looked at me with pity, and I hated it. I was a living reminder of the son they were losing.

The last time I saw him, the last real time, was six months ago. He'd come by to pick up the last of his things. He looked different. Thinner. His clothes were more expensive, but they hung on him wrong. There were faint, purple smudges under his eyes. Anais was waiting for him outside in a sleek, black Mercedes, honking the horn impatiently.

He was stuffing a few old t-shirts into a duffel bag, avoiding my eyes. The room was thick with unspoken words.

"So, this is it?" I finally asked, my voice barely a whisper.

He stopped, his back to me. "I guess. Look, Jona, I'll still be around."

"Will you?" I laughed, a bitter, broken sound. "You haven't been 'around' in months, Kaelo. You live in a different city. A city that just happens to be a twenty-minute drive away."

He finally turned to face me. The old spark, the Kaelo I knew, was gone from his eyes. They were guarded, tired. "It's not like that."

"What is it like, then? Help me understand. Because from where I'm standing, you traded us. You traded this whole life for... for them. For her."

"You don't understand," he said, his voice rising. "They get it. They get me. Anais… she sees who I can be. Not just... this." He gestured vaguely around the room, at the worn posters on the wall, the堆 of books, the shared history. He had dismissed our entire world with a wave of his hand.

And that's when I broke. "And what was this, Kaelo? What were we? Was it nothing? All those years, was it all just a placeholder until something better came along?"

"Of course not!" he shouted, and for a second, I saw a flicker of the boy who was terrified of moths. "Jonas, you're my brother."

"I'm not your brother!" The words ripped out of my throat, raw and bleeding. "I have never, not for one single day, felt like your brother."

The confession hung in the air, vibrating with all the years of repressed longing. His face changed. The anger drained away, replaced by a stunned, dawning comprehension. He looked at me, really looked at me, and I saw the recognition in his eyes. He knew. Maybe he had always known. The space between us was suddenly charged with a different kind of energy, something fragile and terrifying and years too late.

"Jona..." he started, his voice soft, full of a strange new emotion.

The horn blared from outside, a harsh, ugly sound that shattered the moment. Anais. The spell was broken. Kaelo flinched, looking towards the window. He was a dog on a leash, and his master was calling. He zipped up the duffel bag, the sound unnaturally loud in the quiet room.

"I have to go," he said, his voice flat. He wouldn't look at me again. He walked out of the room, out of the house, and out of my life. I stood there, listening to the crunch of gravel as the Mercedes pulled away. The silence he left behind was absolute.

I sank onto my bed, my body trembling. The photograph on my desk caught my eye. Naivasha. The sun, the grass, his arm around me. A better time. A time before Seb and Anais and the slow, painful amputation of our lives. I clutched the photograph so tightly the corners dug into my palm. A desperate, impossible wish formed in my mind, a prayer to a god I didn't believe in. *Take me back. Just let me go back. Let me fix it. Let me go back to that day.*

And the room began to dissolve. It wasn't a violent change, but a slow, syrupy bleed at the edges of my vision. The barking of the neighbour's dog faded, replaced by the distant cry of a fish eagle. The smell of rain and mud was overwhelmed by the scent of damp earth and acacia blossoms. The gray light of my room brightened, warmed, becoming the golden, late-afternoon sun of the Great Rift Valley. My knuckles were white around the photograph, and the cheap plaster wall in front of me shimmered and reformed itself into a vast, shimmering expanse of water. The world pixelated, fractured, and then snapped into focus.

I was sitting on scratchy grass. The air was warm. A heavy arm was thrown around my shoulder.

"You're a million miles away," a voice said, right beside my ear. A voice I thought I'd only ever hear in my memory again. "What are you thinking about so hard, Jona? You'll sprain your brain."

I turned my head, slowly, my heart a frantic drum against my ribs. He was there. Kaelo. Grinning at me, his eyes clear and bright and full of nothing but easy affection. The tiny gap between his front teeth seemed like the most beautiful imperfection in the universe. He was real. He was here. It was two years ago.
