The sun was warm on my skin, the photograph wasn't in my hand, and the world was whole again. It had worked. The impossible wish had been granted. I was back.

My breath hitched, a painful, sharp thing. It wasn't a memory. The weight of his arm was real, solid, a warm, living pressure across my shoulders. The scent of him wasn't a phantom in a lonely room; it was lake water, sunshine, and the faint, cheap soap from the guesthouse bathroom. I could feel the individual blades of grass pricking the back of my legs. For a dizzying second, the two realities warred in my head – the grey, rain-soaked room and this impossible, sun-drenched gold. But the gold was winning. It was real.

A sob tried to tear its way out of my chest, but I swallowed it down, turning it into a choked gasp. I reached up, my hand trembling, and my fingers brushed against his arm, just to be sure. The skin was warm, the muscles beneath it firm. He was solid. He was here. He was whole. The relief that flooded me was so immense, so tidal, it threatened to drown me. I felt tears prick the corners of my eyes, blurring his beloved, familiar face. Kaelo’s grin faltered, replaced by a flicker of concern.

"Whoa, Jona, you okay? You look like you've seen a ghost." He leaned closer, his dark eyes searching mine. The nearness of him, the genuine worry in his expression, was an agony of sweetness. This was the Kaelo I had lost, the one who could read my silences better than anyone. Before the parties, before the money, before he had learned to look through me.

"No," I managed, my voice a raw whisper. "The opposite of a ghost." I gave a shaky, wet-sounding laugh. "Just… it's beautiful here. I think I got overwhelmed." It was a flimsy excuse, but it was the only one I had. I couldn't possibly tell him the truth. *I just came from the future, a future where you destroy us.* I took a deep, shuddering breath, trying to anchor myself in the here and now. The scent of acacia, the warmth of his body, the sound of water lapping against the shore. These were my anchors now.

Kaelo bought it. Or at least, he accepted my explanation because it was easier than probing the strange, sudden depth of emotion in my eyes. He relaxed, his grin returning. "Overwhelmed by grass? My man, you really are a poet." He squeezed my shoulder, a gesture of casual, uncomplicated affection that made my heart ache. "Come on, let's go skip some stones. I bet I can get one all the way to that patch of reeds." He was already scrambling to his feet, pulling me up with him. His hand in mine was calloused and strong.

As we walked towards the water's edge, I felt a new resolve hardening inside me, like cooling steel. This wasn't a dream. This was a second chance. A terrible, beautiful, impossible second chance. The photograph in my old life, the one I had clutched like a holy relic, wasn't a memory anymore. It was a starting point. The fault line hadn't appeared yet. The ground was firm beneath my feet. Anais didn't exist. Seb was just some unknown boy in a future I now had the power to rewrite. Kaelo was still mine. He was my brother, my friend, the keeper of my secrets. And this time, I would not let him go.

He found a perfect flat stone and, with a fluid motion that was pure Kaelo, sent it skittering across the lake’s surface. It bounced seven times before sinking. He let out a whoop of triumph, turning to me with that sun-splitting grin. "Beat that, my brother!" he challenged, his eyes sparkling with life. I looked at him, truly looked at him, and saw not just the boy beside me, but the man I had lost. The ghost I had been mourning was standing right here, vibrant and alive, his future an unwritten page. And I, the quiet tutor, the secret keeper, would be the one to edit the story. This time, there would be a different ending. I would make sure of it. I would save him from them. I would save him for me.

The stone was cool and smooth in my palm, a small, solid piece of the present. I searched for the right words, the right expression, a mask of normalcy to cover the seismic shift that had just occurred within me. I found a faint smile, a shadow of the one he was offering me. "You're on," I said, my voice steadier than I felt. It was the first lie of my new life. The first of many, I suspected. I mimicked his stance, wound my arm back, and flicked my wrist. The stone skipped twice, a pathetic effort, and sank with a quiet 'plop'. Kaelo howled with laughter, a full-throated, joyous sound that echoed across the water. It was a sound I hadn't heard in its pure form for years, unburdened by disappointment or the need to perform for a new, sophisticated audience. I didn't care about the stone; I only cared about that laugh. I wanted to bottle it, to hoard it, to make sure it never faded again.

We spent the next hour in that simple, childish competition. I was clumsy, my mind a turbulent sea of past and future, my movements jerky and uncoordinated. Kaelo, however, was grace personified. He was in his element, a king in his small, temporary kingdom of dust and water and setting sun. I watched him, cataloguing the details I had forgotten or that the future had eroded. The way he bit his lower lip in concentration, the confident set of his shoulders, the sheer, unadulterated life burning in his eyes. This Kaelo hadn't yet learned to be ashamed of his home. He hadn't yet had his accent subtly mocked or his tastes deemed 'rustic'. He hadn't yet learned the poisonous math of comparing his life to others and finding it wanting. He was still just Kaelo, a boy who moved through the world as if it was a party thrown in his honour. And for now, I was his only guest.

As the sun began to dip towards the serrated peaks of the Aberdares, painting the sky in fiery strokes of orange and purple, we collapsed back onto the grass, exhausted and content. The air grew cooler. A profound peace settled over the landscape, a peace that felt both profound and fragile. I knew this peace was an illusion, a temporary ceasefire in a war I had already seen the end of once. This time, I had to be the general, not the casualty. I had to anticipate every move, fortify every weakness.

"KCSEs are going to be hell," Kaelo said, sighing as he stared up at the vast, colourful sky. "I can’t believe this is our last real break before the final push." His voice was laced with a casual dread, the normal anxiety of any student facing national exams. It was a normal conversation, the kind we had had a thousand times. But for me, every word was a clue, every sigh a data point. The KCSEs. The results slip he would wave in my face. The beginning of the end.

"We'll manage," I said, my voice quiet but firm. I rolled onto my side to face him. He was lying on his back, hands laced behind his head. The dying light caught the sharp line of his jaw. "I'll make sure of it." This was more than a promise to help him study; it was a vow. This time, he wouldn't just scrape through. This time, I would build him a foundation so strong that the casual condescension of a boy like Seb would be meaningless. He would not need their validation because he would have his own. "But what about after, Kaelo? Strathmore... is that what you actually want? Business?"

He shrugged, a gesture that made the muscles in his shoulder shift under his t-shirt. "It's a good degree. Dad says it's where the money is. He wants me to be better than him, you know? Not scrambling for contracts, but sitting in a boardroom." There it was. The motivation. David's hope, his booming, infectious hope, was also a pressure, a path laid out for Kaelo that he felt obliged to follow. It was a path that led directly to the Karen set, to the social circles where business deals were made over polo and whiskey.

"There are other ways to make money," I said carefully, testing the waters. "Ways to be 'better'. You're good with people, Kaelo. Not just making friends, but… understanding them. You ever think about something like marketing? Or starting your own thing? Something small, something that's just yours?" I was planting seeds, tiny ideas that might, with enough water and light, grow into a different future. A future where his success wasn't defined by others, in a world that would inevitably reject me.

He turned his head and looked at me, a genuinely curious expression on his face. "My own thing? Like what? Selling roasted maize by the roadside?" he joked, using the same line he would use in two years, but this time it was light, without the weight of a future I knew. I smiled, a real smile this time. "No. Something better. We've got time to think about it. We've got loads of time." For the first time since my dizzying return, I felt a surge of real, unadulterated hope. The path wasn't set in stone. He was listening. He was still listening to me.

The first star pricked the deep indigo of the twilight sky. Kaelo's attention was back on the heavens, his earlier seriousness forgotten. "Look, Jona. A shooting star. Make a wish." He was still a boy who believed in wishes. I didn't need to. Mine had already been granted, a terrifying, cosmic miracle. I looked not at the sky, but at his profile, illuminated by the last vestiges of daylight. I didn't wish for anything. I made a promise. This Kaelo, the one who saw magic in the sky and a future full of vague, hopeful possibilities, was the one I would protect. The fractures that would break him, break us, were still just hairline cracks. And this time, I knew exactly where they were. I was the secret keeper. But now, I would be the gatekeeper, too.

The journey back from Naivasha was a silent film played out against the rattling frame of the old Nissan matatu. Kaelo slept, his head lolling onto my shoulder, his breathing a soft, steady rhythm against my ear. In the future I’d left behind, I would have savoured this accidental intimacy, my own body rigid with a desperate, unspoken longing. Now, it was different. I was a watchman on high alert, and his closeness was a responsibility, a weight of a different kind. I watched the blur of the Kenyan countryside—the acacia trees, the small towns with their brightly painted storefronts, the children waving from the roadside—and it all felt sharper, more precious. This was the world I was fighting for. This was the tapestry I had to stop from unravelling.

Returning to our room in South C was the first real test. I stood in the doorway, my bag slung over my shoulder, and looked at the space that had become my prison. The two beds, the shared desk piled high with textbooks, the worn poster of a rally car Kaelo had taped to the wall. It all looked exactly the same, but my perception of it had been fundamentally altered. This was no longer a monument to loss; it was a command centre. His side of the room, which I had last seen as a hollowed-out shell of his absence, was now vibrant with his presence. A crumpled rugby jersey on the floor, the lingering scent of his soap, a dog-eared novel I had recommended to him. The chasm between our beds had vanished. It was just a narrow strip of floor again, easily crossed.

The campaign began that night. The dread of the KCSEs was Kaelo's primary concern, and that was my opening. In the old timeline, I had simply drilled him, forcing facts and formulas into his head through sheer repetition. My goal had been singular: get him the grades his father wanted. It was an act of service, the homework fixer doing his job. This time, I had to be a teacher, not a tutor. I had to make him think, not just memorise. I pulled out the business studies syllabus, a subject he usually groaned about.

"Forget just revising," I said, my tone deliberately casual as we sat at the desk, the single lamp casting a warm circle of light around us. "Let's do something different. Let's make a real business plan. A proper one. For that idea you had, the small one that's just yours." I was echoing my own words from the lakeside, reinforcing the seed I had planted. He looked at me, his brow furrowed. "What idea? Selling maize?" he asked, a hint of his usual deflection in his voice. "No. Think, Kaelo. What are you good at? People. You collect them, remember? You're a brand. 'Kaelo'. Let's build a business around that. A small events company. Or a customised tour guide thing for people who want to see the real Nairobi, not just the tourist traps. We can use the syllabus as a guide—market research, startup costs, branding."

A flicker of interest sparked in his eyes, supplanting the familiar exam weariness. This wasn't about abstract economic theories anymore; it was about him. It was a game, a puzzle, and he was the main character. For the next two hours, he was more engaged than I had ever seen him. He scribbled ideas on a fresh page of his notebook, his handwriting a chaotic scrawl of enthusiasm. He talked about creating unique party experiences, about connecting local artists with small venues, about organising hiking trips to the Ngong Hills. He was alive with a kind of creative energy I had never thought to tap into before. I was no longer just his saviour from academic failure; I was the architect of his potential. I felt a dizzying sense of power, both terrifying and exhilarating.

Our parents were oblivious, caught up in their own bubble of domestic bliss. My mother, Wanjiru, hummed in the kitchen, the scent of her cooking a comforting blanket over the house. David was perpetually optimistic, his booming laugh the house's primary soundtrack. At dinner that Sunday, the four of us crowded around the small dining table, the scene was so painfully normal it felt like a dream. David, serving himself a mountain of ugali, clapped Kaelo on the back. "Soon you'll be at Strathmore, my boy. Eating in the fancy cafeteria, talking big business ideas. Just like we planned." David’s smile was wide, full of pride and unwavering belief in this one specific future.

I saw Kaelo’s own smile falter for a fraction of a second before he caught himself. He glanced at me, a quick, uncertain look. In the old timeline, he would have just grinned and nodded, accepting the praise and the path it laid out. But now, a seed of another idea was sprouting. "Yeah, Dad," he said, his voice lacking its usual conviction. "Maybe." David didn't notice the hesitation, but I did. It was a tiny crack in the foundation of his expectations, and I knew I had to wedge it wider. "Kaelo's been coming up with some of his own business ideas," I interjected smoothly, earning a sharp, warning look from Kaelo that I ignored. "He's got a real mind for marketing."

My mother looked intrigued. "Oh? Like what?" she asked, her kind eyes resting on Kaelo. Kaelo, put on the spot, flushed. "It's nothing, just… Jonas's idea for revision. Some stuff about… events," he mumbled, suddenly shy. But David laughed, a sound that was meant to be encouraging but landed like a dismissal. "That's good, that's good! Get the mind working. You'll need that energy for your corporate strategy classes. The real world is about boardrooms and balance sheets, not parties." The conversation moved on, but the moment hung in the air for me. I had met my primary obstacle. It wasn't a villain; it was a father's love, a father's dream. And it was more powerful than any enemy.

Later that night, the space between our beds felt charged again, but not with distance. It hummed with conspiracy. "Why did you say that to Dad?" Kaelo whispered in the dark. The streetlights cast long shadows across the room. "He thinks my ideas are a joke." I could hear the hurt in his voice, the sting of his father's casual dismissal. "He doesn't think they're a joke," I whispered back, choosing my words with the care of a bomb disposal expert. "He just has a different picture in his head. A picture he's had for a long time. It's hard for people to see a new picture when they love the old one so much."

I sat up, looking over at the shape of him in his bed. "But it doesn't matter what he thinks right now. It's your life, Kaelo. Your future. The business plan… it's not just for revision anymore, is it?" He was silent for a long moment. I could almost hear the gears turning in his head, weighing his father's dream against a new, fragile one of his own. "No," he said finally, his voice soft but clear in the darkness. "I think… I think it could be real." A wave of triumph washed over me, so potent I felt light-headed. This was progress. This was a deviation from the script. I had made him see a different door, and he was considering opening it. I had to keep him here, in this room, dreaming with me, where the temptations of a richer, colder world couldn't reach him. This time, I would be his brightest flame.

The months leading up to the KCSEs transformed our room into a command centre, a war room for a battle fought on two fronts. The first was against calculus and the complex history of the East African Protectorate. The second, my secret war, was for Kaelo’s soul. Our shared desk disappeared under a blizzard of papers: my neat, colour-coded revision notes lay alongside Kaelo’s sprawling, chaotic mind-maps. We didn’t just revise; we strategized. I reframed every subject through the lens of the nascent business plan we had christened ‘Nairobi Unlocked’. Economics wasn’t just theory; it was the blueprint for our startup costs. English wasn’t just literature; it was crafting the perfect pitch to a potential client. For the first time, Kaelo wasn’t just studying to pass; he was studying to build. He would pace the small room, energized and full of ideas, using a ruler as a prop while he practiced a presentation for an imaginary investor, his only audience me, sitting on my bed, playing the role of stern-faced banker.

Our friendship, which had been fading into silence in the other life, found its voice again in these late-night sessions. The silence was filled not with the ghosts of unspoken feelings, but with shared purpose. We laughed more than we had in years, the sound rich and easy in the small room. Kaelo’s charisma, which I had once watched with a kind of detached admiration, was now a tool I was helping him sharpen. He was the frontman, the visionary, the heart of Nairobi Unlocked. I was the strategist, the logistician, the one who made sure the beautiful, chaotic ideas could actually work. We were a team, a closed circuit of energy and ambition. The world outside our room, with its barking dogs and muddy lanes, ceased to matter. We were building our own world on sheets of foolscap paper, a world where he was the star and I was his indispensable right hand.

The first test of Nairobi Unlocked came in the form of the ‘Post-KCSE Blowout Bash’, Kaelo’s name for it. In the past, this would have been an aimless gathering in someone’s backyard. Now, it was our pilot project. Kaelo designed an intricate, hand-drawn invitation that he photocopied at the local cybercafé. I created a meticulous budget on a spreadsheet, accounting for every shilling needed for sodas, snacks, and hiring a cheap sound system. We weren’t just throwing a party; we were executing an event. We found a small, unused community hall for a pittance, and Kaelo, using the charm that was his superpower, convinced the owner to let us have it for an extra three hours. He was in his element, negotiating, persuading, connecting. I watched him, a fierce pride swelling in my chest. This was the Kaelo I was fighting for, a leader in his own right, in his own world.

David stumbled upon our spreadsheet one evening, left open on the desk. He peered at it over my shoulder, his brow furrowed, then let out a booming laugh. "Look at this, Wanjiru! My boy is already doing financial projections!" He clapped Kaelo on the shoulder, his face beaming with pride. "This is excellent practice. All this planning, this attention to detail… that's the kind of thinking that gets you a corner office at a big firm. Strathmore will polish you into a real diamond." Kaelo and I exchanged a fleeting, secret glance. David had seen what he wanted to see, interpreting our rebellion as practice for conformity. He was cheering for the very tools we were using to build our escape route. I felt a cold knot of guilt, a liar’s triumph. It was a dangerous game, letting him believe this, but it was necessary. We needed his blessing, even if it was for a future we had no intention of living.

The day of the party, our small house was a hive of activity. My mother, fully won over by Kaelo’s infectious enthusiasm, had spent the morning making samosas and chapatis, her contribution to our ‘catering budget’. As we loaded boxes of soda into a borrowed handcart, Kaelo paused, wiping a sheen of sweat from his forehead. He looked at me, his usual joking manner gone, replaced by a quiet sincerity that was far more potent. "Jona," he said, "I wouldn't be able to do any of this without you. You know that, right? You make all my crazy ideas seem… possible." In the future I had fled, his gratitude had been a whirlwind of relief after an exam he’d almost failed. This was different. This wasn’t about being saved from failure; it was about being seen, about being enabled to succeed. It was the foundation of a partnership, not a debt. "We're a team," I said, my voice thick with emotion. It was the truest thing I had ever said.

That night, lying in the darkness, the faint thrum of the city a lullaby outside our window, I felt the weight of my actions settle upon me. I was no longer a passive observer of Kaelo’s life. I was an active, clandestine participant in its design. Every piece of advice, every shared joke, every late-night study session was a carefully placed stone, diverting the river of his life away from the path I knew led to a barren delta. I was pulling him away from Seb, from Anais, from the person he was becoming. But in doing so, I was also pulling him closer to me, binding him to this life, to this room, to our shared dream. The memory of his lost, tired eyes in that future apartment, the way he had dismissed our world with a wave of his hand, was the only justification I needed. I would be his anchor, whether he knew he needed one or not. I would hold him to this shore.

The exams finished on a hot, dusty Tuesday. We walked out of the school gates for the last time as students, blinking in the harsh afternoon sun. The air was thick with the shouts and cheers of our classmates, a collective exhalation of years of pressure. Kaelo was incandescent, a live wire of pure energy. He threw his arm around me, not in a hug of relief, but in a gesture of triumphant conspiracy. The weight was lifted. He was free. He looked at me, his grin wide and familiar, but his eyes held a new kind of fire, one I had lit. "It's done," he said, his voice buzzing. "Now, the real work begins. Nairobi Unlocked, Phase One. Are you ready?" I looked at my friend, my brother, my project, my whole world, and I smiled. The first and easiest battle had been won. The ground felt firm, the future was unwritten, and for now, I held the pen.

The long vacation after the exams was not a period of rest. It was a breathless, three-month sprint, the official launch of our shared dream. Nairobi Unlocked began not with a bang, but with a pair of bewildered but game Dutch tourists whom Kaelo had charmed at a coffee shop near the national archives. They had been planning a trip to the giraffe centre, the standard, sterile Nairobi experience. Kaelo, with a conspiratorial grin and an arsenal of stories, offered them something else. He offered them the city’s heartbeat. And I, trailing behind with a map and a meticulously planned itinerary, provided the skeleton that gave his enchanting promises flesh. We led them through the roaring chaos of Gikomba market, Kaelo translating the rapid-fire Swahili of the traders, his laughter a bridge between two worlds. We navigated them to a tiny, unmarked eatery behind a bus station that served the best nyama choma in the city, the kind of place they would never find on their own. I handled the logistics, the timings, the discreet payments, while Kaelo was the main event. He was the storyteller, the diplomat, the embodiment of Nairobi’s vibrant soul. Watching him, I saw the raw material of the man he was supposed to become, but this time, he was being forged in a fire I controlled, not one that would consume him.

We made a respectable amount of money from that first tour, and then another from a family visiting from the UK. The wad of shillings we counted out on Kaelo’s bed felt more real, more valuable, than any exam grade. It was proof. It was the first brick in the new future I was building. Kaelo was ecstatic, a whirlwind of plans and ambitions. He wanted to design t-shirts, create a website, print proper business cards. His energy was boundless, and it filled every corner of our small room, pushing out the last of the shadows of the future I’d left behind. The business was our world, our shared language. My love for him, once a silent, aching secret, was now laundered through spreadsheets and strategy meetings. It was poured into the logistical support that allowed him to shine. I could love him openly, fiercely, as long as I called it a partnership. It was a perfect, sustainable deception.

Our parents watched this whirlwind of activity with mixed reactions. My mother, Wanjiru, was our quiet champion. She saw the light back in Kaelo’s eyes, the purpose in his step, and she approved. She offered business advice gleaned from her years of running a small tailoring stall, her wisdom practical and grounding. David, however, saw our venture as a charming, but ultimately juvenile, hobby. He’d watch Kaelo practice a sales pitch in the living room and chuckle, a deep, rumbling sound of paternal affection. “That’s the spirit, my boy! Sharpening your teeth for the real world,” he’d say. “This little tour business is great fun, but just wait until you’re pitching to a board of directors. That’s the real game.” Every word of praise was a subtle dismissal, a reminder that he saw this as a temporary diversion before the main act: Strathmore. Kaelo would just smile, but I saw the flicker of defiance in his eyes, a look that wouldn't have been there two years ago. He was starting to believe in our game more than his father’s.

The day the KCSE results were released, a heavy, expectant silence fell over the house. This was the moment that, in the other timeline, had propelled everything forward. In that life, it had been a day of sheer relief, the validation of my tutoring, the moment Kaelo had clung to me and called me his saviour. Now, it felt different. I wasn't anxious about whether he had passed; I knew he had. My campaign had been too thorough, too relentless. I was anxious about how well he had done. I had a sickening premonition that my efforts to build his confidence had perhaps been too successful, that in arming him against insecurity, I might have inadvertently gilded the cage I was trying to help him escape. We all gathered in the living room as David returned from the post office, holding the tell-tale brown envelope. My mother twisted her hands in the fabric of her skirt. Kaelo was trying to look nonchalant, but he was bouncing his leg, a nervous energy I knew all too well.

David, ever the showman, held the envelope aloft. "The future is in this envelope," he declared, his voice booming. He handed it to Kaelo, whose fingers trembled slightly as he took it. He tore it open, his eyes scanning the slip of paper inside. The colour drained from his face. For a terrifying second, I thought I had failed, that my calculations were wrong. Then he looked up, his eyes wide with disbelief, and he looked straight at me. A slow, stunned smile spread across his face. He didn't yell. He didn't whoop. He just handed the paper to his father, his gaze still locked on mine. David took it, his eyes scanning the results. His cheerful demeanor vanished, replaced by a profound, shaking awe. He looked at Kaelo, then at the paper, then back at Kaelo. "My God," David whispered, his voice thick with emotion. He read the grades aloud, a string of straight A's and A-minuses, grades that didn't just meet the entry requirements for Strathmore but smashed them to pieces. These were the grades of a scholar, not a boy who had just scraped through. Wanjiru gasped, tears welling in her eyes as she hugged a still-shocked Kaelo. But I wasn't celebrating. A cold dread, colder than any I had felt in my lonely room in the future, washed over me. David turned to me, his eyes shining with a new, intense respect. "Jonas," he said, his voice full of wonder. "You didn't just save him. You turned him into a genius." He then turned back to Kaelo, his hand clapping him on the back, his voice regaining its boom, now amplified by unshakeable pride. "A genius! With these grades, you won't just go to Strathmore, my son. You will own that place! Any door will open for you now. Any door!" The triumph in his voice was a death knell. I had not built Kaelo an escape route. I had built a gilded, four-lane highway leading directly to the heart of the world I had to save him from, and his father was now the gleeful, proud driver.

The celebration that evening was a suffocating affair. David, incandescent with a pride that bordered on manic, had invited the neighbours and a few of his business associates. Our small living room, usually a cozy haven, felt crowded and loud, the air thick with the smell of roasting meat from a celebratory goat and the syrupy sweetness of congratulatory words. I navigated the throng with a fixed smile, a plate of food I couldn't eat growing cold in my hands. Every person who clapped Kaelo on the back, who called him a genius, who spoke of his brilliant future in corporate law or international business, felt like a pallbearer at a funeral only I was attending. They were celebrating the death of our quiet, shared world, and they didn’t even know it. I was a ghost at the feast of my own making, my triumph a bitter ash in my mouth.

Kaelo was the sun around which everyone orbited. He accepted the praise with a dazed, almost shy grace that everyone found endearing. But I saw something else. I saw the way his eyes kept finding mine across the noisy room, a silent, questioning look that I couldn't decipher. Was it a plea for reassurance? A shared moment of disbelief? Or was he looking for my approval, for my permission to enjoy this unexpected ascent? In the old timeline, his success was my success, his relief my relief. Now, his victory felt like a betrayal, and the guilt of that thought was a physical weight in my chest. He was not the enemy. The future he represented was. But in the adoring eyes of everyone in that room, he and that future were now one and the same.

Later, when the last guest had finally departed and the house had settled into a humming silence, we stood in the kitchen, stacking dirty plates. My mother and David were in the living room, their voices a low, happy murmur. The air between Kaelo and me was charged with everything that had gone unsaid all evening. He picked up a plate, scrubbing at a stubborn spot with more force than necessary. The small, repetitive motion was the only sound for a long moment. Finally, he spoke, his voice quiet, not looking at me. "It's crazy, isn't it?"

"It's what we worked for," I replied, my voice carefully neutral. I couldn't let the panic show. I had to be the anchor, the calm centre. "You earned it."

"No," he said, turning from the sink to face me fully. The dazed look was gone, replaced by an intense clarity. "We earned it. Jona, I wouldn't have gotten a single 'A' without you. You didn't just drill me. You changed the way I think." He took a step closer, his eyes searching mine. "This... this changes things, doesn't it?" Here it was. The question that had been hanging over me like a guillotine. The fork in the road had appeared, earlier and more starkly than I had ever anticipated.

"Why would it?" I asked, my heart hammering against my ribs. "The plan is the plan. Nairobi Unlocked. This is just... a grade on a piece of paper. It doesn't change who you are. It doesn't change what we want to build." My words sounded desperate even to my own ears, a frantic attempt to hold back a tide.

He ran a hand through his hair, a gesture of frustration and confusion. "But it does change things! Dad is already talking about special scholarship programs, about connecting me with his old university friends who are partners at big firms. It’s not just a degree anymore, Jona. It’s a key. A key to that whole other world." His voice wasn't filled with the dazzled excitement I had dreaded; it was filled with a worrying, pragmatic curiosity. In the old timeline, he had been a moth drawn to the flame. Now, he was a strategist, considering how to harness the fire.

This was a new, more dangerous Kaelo. The one I had unwittingly created. "And you want that world?" I pushed, needing to know. "The world of Seb and his 'cozy' houses and polo matches? The world that looks down on everything we are?" The memory of Seb's condescending smile was a weapon, and I wielded it without shame. Kaelo flinched, the name a sharp reminder of a future he didn't know he'd had. "No! Of course not," he said quickly, defensively. "But you're not thinking big enough, Jona. We've been thinking small, Gikomba tours and a few shillings. With the connections I could make at a place like Strathmore... real connections... we could get actual investment. We could turn Nairobi Unlocked into something huge. Something real. We wouldn't have to borrow handcarts; we could have our own fleet of vans. We wouldn't have to charm community hall owners; we could have our own office."

A cold, terrifying understanding dawned on me. He didn't want to leave our world for theirs. He wanted to invite their world into ours. He saw their money, their influence, their connections as a resource to be exploited, an arsenal for our small rebellion. He couldn't see what I saw, what I knew with the certainty of a man who had already lived it: that their world was a Trojan horse. It would arrive looking like a gift, full of promises of power and expansion, and once inside our gates, it would destroy everything from within. Anais wouldn't just be a girlfriend; she'd be a potential investor. Seb wouldn't be a snob; he'd be a networking opportunity. The thought made me sick. I looked at the boy I had fought so hard to save, and saw him eagerly planning to build the very bridge I was trying to burn. He saw a ladder; I saw a leash. I had to make him see it too, before he took the first step.

My mind raced, scrambling for a counter-offensive. Arguing with him now, while the scent of his father’s pride and the echoes of congratulations still filled the air, would be a fatal error. I would look petty, jealous, afraid. He would see me as the small-minded boy from South C, trying to keep him tethered to a life he was now demonstrably capable of transcending. I couldn’t fight his ambition with fear; I had to fight it with evidence. He saw a world of opportunity; I had to show him the price of admission. The Trojan horse was on its way, and my only choice was to give him a guided tour of its treacherous interior before he threw open the gates.

A few days later, after the excitement had subsided into a steady hum of future-planning, I put my new strategy into motion. We were in our room, the business plan for Nairobi Unlocked spread between us on the floor. It was my opening. "You were right," I began, my voice measured and thoughtful. I had to concede ground to gain it. "We need to think bigger. Your idea about targeting a wealthier clientele, getting real investment... it's smart. But we know nothing about that world, Kaelo. We can’t sell an 'authentic' experience to people whose lives we don't understand." I tapped a pen against a blank page titled ‘Market Research: The High-End Sector’. "We need to do some reconnaissance. Go where they go. See what they see. Understand what they value."

Kaelo’s eyes lit up, exactly as I knew they would. My apparent agreement with his vision disarmed him completely. He saw me as a willing co-conspirator in his grand plan, not as the saboteur I was. "Exactly!" he said, leaning forward eagerly. "That's what I've been saying. Where do we start? The Windsor? The Muthaiga Club?" He was naming places we’d only ever heard of, places of mythic exclusivity. "Too high," I said, shaking my head. "We can't get into those places. We need somewhere public, but... aspirational. Somewhere we can just watch. Observe." I paused, as if the idea were just coming to me. "What about one of those garden cafés out in Karen? The ones that are always in the Sunday papers. We'll just have a coffee. We'll call it a business expense." Kaelo grinned, slapping me on the back. "Jonas, my brother, my strategist. It's perfect. A spy mission into the land of the rich." He had no idea how right he was.

The following Saturday, we took a series of matatus that felt like a journey across class divides, the vehicles becoming less crowded and the roads smoother with each transfer. We finally arrived in Karen, a suburb that breathed a different kind of air, scented with money and manicured lawns. The café I had chosen was an oasis of curated rustic charm, all weathered wood, wrought iron furniture, and lush, flowering creepers. The patrons spoke in low, confident tones, a stark contrast to the boisterous energy of our usual haunts. Waiters moved with a silent, practiced efficiency. It was beautiful, peaceful, and utterly alien. We found a small table in a corner, and I felt Kaelo’s posture shift beside me. He straightened his back, subtly trying to mimic the relaxed, proprietary air of the people around us. He was already trying to fit in.

For the first hour, we just watched, whispering our observations like trainee spies. Kaelo was fascinated, pointing out the expensive watches, the designer handbags, the casual way people ordered hundred-shilling bottles of water. He saw it all as aspirational data. "See that group over there?" he murmured, nodding towards a table of young people, all glowing with the easy confidence of inherited wealth. "They look like university students. That's our target demographic, Jona. The next generation. The ones who want something cool and different to post on their Instagram." He was seeing clients. I was seeing a pack of wolves.

The group was loud, their laughter sharp and ringing with an edge of mockery as they scrolled through their phones. A young man with pale, freckled skin and a lazy drawl was holding court. For a heart-stopping moment, I thought it was Seb, but it wasn't. It was just his type, a perfect replica. He was telling a story about a disastrous trip to a local club, his voice dripping with condescending amusement. "It was just so... loud," he said, drawing out the word. "And everyone was sweating on us. It was utterly peak." His friends laughed, a sound devoid of any real warmth. Then, the young man’s gaze drifted and settled, for a brief moment, on our table. He looked at Kaelo, then at me. His eyes weren't hostile; they were blank. It was a look of utter disinterest, the kind of look you give a piece of furniture that is neither useful nor offensive. He registered our presence and then, in the same instant, dismissed us as irrelevant. He turned back to his friends, and we were gone from his reality.

I felt Kaelo tense beside me. He had felt it too, that casual, complete erasure. He had spent his whole life being the centre of attention, his charisma a magnetic force that drew people in. And here, in this place he saw as his future, his superpower was useless. He was invisible. To cover his discomfort, he tried to catch the eye of a passing waiter. He raised his hand slightly, a polite gesture we used in the city eateries. The waiter’s eyes flicked towards him and then straight past, as if he hadn't seen. Kaelo’s hand dropped. A faint flush crept up his neck. Here, you didn’t raise your hand. You simply existed with an aura of expectation, and service materialised. It was a language he didn't speak, and his attempt at communication had just marked him as a tourist.

The final, brutal lesson came when we paid. I had budgeted for it, but the bill for two coffees and a shared slice of cake was still shocking, enough to feed our family for two days. As I counted out the shillings, I saw the pale young man from the other table pay his group’s much larger bill. He didn’t count. He just pulled a thick roll of notes from his pocket, peeled a few off, and dropped them on the table, not even waiting for the change. The casualness of the gesture was louder than any insult. It was a demonstration of a life so far removed from ours that money wasn't a number to be calculated, but an infinite resource to be discarded. It was the final, unspoken word on the chasm that separated his world from ours.

The matatu ride home was steeped in a thick, uncomfortable silence. Kaelo stared out the window, the confident strategist from that morning completely gone. The manicured lawns of Karen gave way to the dusty, chaotic streets of our part of the city, and the transition felt more jarring than ever. He had not been charmed or inspired. He had been dismissed. He had been made to feel small and clumsy and poor, and it was a feeling I knew he had never experienced before. I had wanted to show him the truth, and the truth had been merciless. As we walked the final stretch to our house, down the muddy lane past the barking dog, I finally broke the silence, keeping my voice gentle, analytical. "Their money isn't just in the bank, is it?" I said softly. "It's in their accents. It's in the way they sit. It's in how they call a waiter. It’s a language they’ve been speaking since birth." I paused, letting the words sink in. "We can't just learn that language, Kaelo. They can smell a translator a mile away."

He stopped walking and turned to me, his face a mask of frustration and a dawning, bitter understanding. The confident fire in his eyes had been replaced by a troubled, uncertain flicker. "So what?" he shot back, his voice raw. "So we just give up? We stick to Gikomba and selling samosas because we're not good enough to sit at their table?" "No," I said, meeting his gaze, my heart aching for the pain I had deliberately inflicted on him. "It means we stop trying to get a seat at their table." I took a step closer, my voice dropping to an intense whisper. "It means we build our own damn table. A table so strong and so real that they'll be begging us for a seat." I had wounded him, but it was a surgeon’s cut. I had exposed the disease. Now, I was offering the cure. A future forged not by joining them, but by beating them. I watched his face, praying that the seed of resentment I had just planted would grow into a rebellion, not a surrender.

Kaelo stared at me, his chest rising and falling rapidly. The muddy lane, the distant barking of the dog, the whole shabby scenery of our world seemed to hold its breath, waiting for his verdict. The frustration in his eyes was a storm, but my words were a lightning rod, giving the chaotic energy a direction. The shame that had hunched his shoulders just moments before began to burn away, reforged into a harder, sharper resolve. He clenched his fists at his sides, the knuckles white. He looked from our worn-out shoes, to the peeling paint on a nearby wall, and then back to my face, his eyes blazing with a new, dangerous light. It was the look of a king who had just been reminded that his shabby kingdom was still his to command.

"Our own table," he repeated, the words a low growl. He let out a short, sharp laugh, a sound devoid of humour but full of bitter energy. "You're right. You're absolutely right. To hell with them. To hell with their little garden cafés and their quiet money and their stupid, boring lives." He took a step towards me, his face alight with the fervent energy of a new convert. "We don't need their investment. We don't need their approval. We are the prize, Jona. This city, our city, is the prize. We’ve been trying to sell it to people who already think they own the world. We need to find the people who are still looking for it." The surrender was gone, replaced by an intoxicating, rebellious fury. He had not just accepted my premise; he had made it his own, amplifying it with the full force of his wounded pride. The war had been declared, and I had just handed my king his standard.

Back in our room, the atmosphere was electric. The business plan, once a symbol of our shared hope, now looked naive, tainted by the ambition to please a world that despised us. Without a word, Kaelo took the page titled ‘Market Research: The High-End Sector’ and ripped it cleanly in half, then in half again, letting the pieces flutter into the wastebasket. It was a baptism, a cleansing. We spent the next hours huddled on the floor, redrawing our battle lines. Our motto, ‘Build Our Own Table’, was scribbled in thick black marker at the top of a fresh sheet of paper. Nairobi Unlocked was no longer about providing a curated, palatable ‘experience’. It was about offering an unapologetic immersion. Our target market shifted from the wealthy and cynical to the curious and adventurous: backpackers, academics, artists, people who didn't want a sanitized version of Africa but the noisy, vibrant, complicated truth. We would be the gatekeepers to the real Nairobi, not just its tour guides.

The spectre of Strathmore, however, still loomed over us, a gilded cage waiting to snap shut. Kaelo brought it up a week later, the anxiety returning to his eyes. "What about Dad?" he asked, his voice low. "He’s already filled out the preliminary application forms. He talks about it every single day. If I tell him I'm not going, that I want to run our little tour business instead, he'll… he won't just be disappointed, Jona. He'll be broken." He was right. A direct refusal would be seen as an act of petulant rebellion, a betrayal of his father’s deepest dream. I had anticipated this, and my counter-move was ready. I leaned back against my bed, affecting an air of calm strategy. "So you go," I said simply. Kaelo stared at me, bewildered. "What? But that's their world! We just agreed—"

"You go," I interrupted, my voice firm and low, "but you go as our spy. You go to Strathmore to learn how their world works, to understand their strategies, their finances, their networks. You learn how to build a corporate empire, and you bring that knowledge back here, to us. You use their library, you use their computer labs, you listen to their professors. You let them think they are polishing you into one of them, while all along, you are gathering the weapons we need to build our own empire. You won't be joining them, Kaelo. You'll be infiltrating them." I watched the idea dawn on his face, the brilliance of its deception appealing to his newfound rebellious streak. It was the perfect solution: a lie that would allow him to be a loyal son and a revolutionary leader at the same time. He wouldn't be surrendering; he'd be going behind enemy lines. A slow, dangerous smile spread across his face. "A spy," he whispered, tasting the word. "I like it."

The family dinner where Kaelo announced his decision was one of the most difficult performances of my life. I sat with a polite smile, a silent co-conspirator, as Kaelo, with a carefully crafted speech we had rehearsed for two nights, told his father he would be honoured to accept a place at Strathmore. David’s reaction was explosive. He shot up from his chair, his eyes shining with tears, and enveloped Kaelo in a bone-crushing hug. His booming voice filled the house as he spoke of legacy, of pride, of a future secured. "This is it, Wanjiru!" he exclaimed, his face radiant with joy. "This is the day our son's life truly begins!" My mother smiled, her happiness genuine, but as she looked from David's ecstatic face to Kaelo's controlled expression, and then to my own quiet watchfulness, a flicker of something unsettled crossed her features. It was a tiny crack in her joy, a barely perceptible frown that suggested she sensed a harmony that was just slightly off-key. She was hearing the notes we were playing, but she was also hearing the ones we were deliberately leaving out.

In the months before university began, we threw ourselves into the newly radicalised Nairobi Unlocked. Our new clients, a pair of postgraduate anthropology students from Canada, were the perfect test case. Kaelo didn't just take them to a market; he introduced them to the intricate, invisible economies that held it together. He didn't just point out landmarks; he told them the stories of the political protests and community triumphs that had taken place on those very streets. He was magnificent. His charisma was no longer just a tool for making friends; it was a lens through which others could see the soul of the city. He wasn't performing anymore; he was testifying. I handled the logistics with a quiet intensity, my spreadsheets and timetables the invisible scaffolding that allowed his passionate sermons to soar. We were a perfect, self-contained system, our shared purpose a powerful, binding force that left no room for anything or anyone else.

As I lay in my bed one night, listening to the soft sound of Kaelo’s breathing from across the room, the full weight of my creation settled on me. I had averted the future I so dreaded. Kaelo was not drifting away; he was more anchored to me, to our life, than ever before. There would be no Seb, no Anais, no casual dismissal of our world. But this victory was built on a foundation of profound manipulation. I had nurtured his pride and then wounded it. I had offered him a new dream and then turned him into a liar to achieve it. The love I felt for him, a pure, painful ache in the past, was now a complex, controlling force. It was the love of a creator for his creation, fiercely protective yet terrifyingly proprietary. I had saved him from a future where he left me, only to build a new one where he couldn't. I had kept him, but I wondered, with a sudden, chilling clarity, if I had broken him in the process, remaking him into the image of what I needed him to be.

The first few weeks of Kaelo’s life at Strathmore were a triumph for my secret campaign. Our room, which I had dreaded would feel empty and haunted, instead became an intelligence headquarters. Kaelo would return each evening, not with the dazzled eyes of a boy discovering a new world, but with the cynical, focused gaze of a deep-cover agent. He’d shrug off his smart new blazer—a concession to the university’s dress code that his father had purchased with immense pride—and immediately transform back into my Kaelo, collapsing onto his bed and delivering his report. He dissected his lectures on corporate finance not as lessons to be absorbed, but as enemy tactics to be learned and countered. He described his classmates with the detached analysis of an anthropologist, cataloguing their casual wealth, their inherited networks, and their profound ignorance of the city that existed beyond their gated communities.

“They talk about ‘emerging markets’ like it’s a place on another planet, not ten minutes down the road,” he’d say, a note of derisive wonder in his voice. “They have no idea how anything actually works. They think Gikomba is just a place you go with a tour guide for a 'cultural experience'. They’re tourists in their own country, Jona.” Each word was a balm to my anxious soul, a confirmation that my strategy was working. He was being vaccinated against their world, building an immunity through exposure. We would take his notes on supply chain management and apply them to our own fledgling business, laughing at the irony of using a multi-million shilling education to figure out the most efficient way to buy sodas in bulk for a walking tour. He was my spy, our spy, and he was perfect. The old fear receded, replaced by a quiet, steady confidence. I had not just averted disaster; I had created a masterpiece of counter-insurgency.

The first crack in my perfect fortress appeared so subtly I almost missed it. It wasn't a person or an event, but a word. Kaelo was describing a particularly clueless marketing lecturer and ended with, “The whole lecture was just… peak.” The word landed in the quiet of our room with the alien clatter of a dropped coin. It was their slang, the slang of the pale boy at the Karen café. In the old timeline, he had adopted their language as a desperate attempt to belong. He said it now with a smirk, as if in mockery, but the word came too easily, it fit too naturally in his mouth. I said nothing, dismissing it as a side effect of his immersion, a piece of camouflage he had forgotten to take off. But a few days later, it was a name: Seb.

“We got assigned a group project in macroeconomics,” Kaelo said, tossing his bag onto his bed. “I’m with this one girl, and this guy, Seb. He’s a piece of work. Thinks he knows everything because his dad is some big shot ambassador.” A cold fist clenched in my stomach. Seb. It couldn't be the same one. It was a common enough name. But the description—the casual arrogance, the ambassador father—was too precise to be a coincidence. The ghost I thought I had banished had just walked through the wall. "What's he like?" I asked, my voice tight. Kaelo shrugged, pulling a textbook from his bag. “Arrogant. Lazy. But he's not stupid. He knows his theory, just has no idea how to apply it. He keeps talking about polo. Who even plays polo?” Kaelo rolled his eyes, a gesture of solidarity meant for me. But I saw the subtle shift. He wasn't just describing a caricature; he was describing a person, with flaws and, unnervingly, with strengths.

I tried to reinforce the narrative, to bring him back to the safety of our shared disdain. "He's the enemy, Kaelo. The perfect example of what we're fighting against. The kind of person who would look straight through us in a café." My words, which had once been a rallying cry, now sounded defensive, almost pleading. Kaelo looked up from his book, his brow furrowed with a flicker of impatience. “I know that, Jona. But he’s in my group. I have to work with him. You said it yourself: I'm supposed to be learning how their world works. You can’t do that if you refuse to even talk to them.” He was using my own logic against me, turning my carefully constructed strategy into a license to fraternize. The student was beginning to question the teacher. A new, terrifying thought entered my mind: what if the vaccination wasn’t working? What if, instead of building immunity, it was just suppressing the symptoms?

The group project forced them together. Kaelo’s evening reports began to change. They were still laced with cynicism, but now there were anecdotes that weren't entirely mocking. Seb, it turned out, had a dry, cutting wit that Kaelo, a connoisseur of humour, couldn't help but appreciate. Seb had connections that could, theoretically, be useful. "He knows the manager at this new hotel in Westlands," Kaelo mentioned one night, almost as an aside. "We were talking about Nairobi Unlocked—I was just feeling him out, seeing his reaction—and he said we should pitch a proposal to them for their international guests. He said he could get us a meeting." I felt a wave of nausea. He was discussing our secret rebellion with the enemy. "And you trust him?" I asked, my voice sharper than I intended. "Of course not," Kaelo shot back, defensive. "But it's an opportunity, isn't it? Isn't that the point of this whole 'spy' mission? To find opportunities? Or is the point just to sit here and feel superior?" The accusation stung, because it held a grain of truth. My strategy had been born of fear, a desire to keep him safe, to keep him mine. His interpretation of it was bolder, more ambitious, and infinitely more dangerous.

The inevitable invitation came a week later. Kaelo was uncharacteristically hesitant as he brought it up. "So, Seb's cousin is having a birthday party this Saturday," he began, not looking at me. "At their house. He said I should come. The whole project group is going." The words hung in the air, a perfect echo of a conversation from another life. But the context was all wrong. He wasn't dazzled. He was framing it as a strategic obligation. "I don't think I should go," he said, and I knew it was a test. He was giving me the power of veto, forcing me to be the cautious one, the one holding him back. If I said no, I would be undermining the very mission I had designed. I would be the timid general afraid to send his soldier into the field. I was trapped in the web of my own making. "You should go," I said, the words feeling like stones in my mouth. "It's a perfect intelligence-gathering opportunity. See who's there. Find out what they talk about. It’s for Nairobi Unlocked."

He looked relieved, his brief hesitation vanishing, replaced by a flicker of something I couldn't read. Was it excitement? "You should come too, Jona," he offered, but it was a reflex, a hollow echo of the past. We both knew I wouldn't. We both knew I couldn't. "I have to work on the accounts," I said, the lie slipping out easily. It was the same excuse as before. "Oh. Okay," he said, the disappointment in his voice fleeting, quickly replaced by the practical considerations of his mission. He was already somewhere else, planning his infiltration, selecting his camouflage.

On Saturday evening, as Kaelo got ready, the old dread returned with a suffocating intensity. He dressed with care, choosing a smart shirt my mother had helped him buy. He looked older, more polished. He was a perfect chameleon, ready to blend into the enemy’s territory. As he was about to leave, he paused at the door, turning back to me. "Don't worry," he said, his expression serious. "I know what I'm doing. I'm not them, Jona. I'm just learning their language." He gave me a quick, reassuring smile, but it didn't reach his eyes. Then he was gone. I stood in the middle of our room, listening to his footsteps fade down the hallway. The silence he left behind was absolute, a perfect replica of the silence I had known in the future. I had given him the confidence, the strategy, the language to navigate a world I was terrified of. I had armed him, trained him, and sent him on a mission, only to realize with sickening certainty that I had no control over what he would do with those weapons once he was out of my sight. The timeline hadn't been broken. It was bending back, pulled by a terrible, familiar gravity, and my own hands had been the ones to give it the push.

The hours that followed Kaelo’s departure were a slow, grinding torture. I sat at our desk, the Nairobi Unlocked accounts open in front of me, but the columns of figures were meaningless squiggles. My mind was not in our small room in South C; it was across the city, in a house I had never seen in this life but knew with the intimate dread of a recurring nightmare. I pictured Kaelo navigating the rooms, a glass in his hand, my carefully crafted cynicism his only shield. But I knew, with a certainty that was a cold sickness in my gut, that a shield can be heavy. A shield can be set aside. The silence in our room was a living entity. It breathed in the spaces between the familiar night sounds—the distant traffic, the neighbour’s cough—and exhaled a profound, suffocating loneliness. This was the silence I had run from, the silence that had been my constant companion in the future I’d erased. And now it was back, a patient predator that had been waiting for me all along.

I picked up the Naivasha photograph, my thumb tracing the outline of Kaelo’s grinning face. It was no longer a starting point, a symbol of my second chance. It was a picture from a history that felt as distant and unattainable as my first life. In the photo, I was looking at him, my joy a reflection of his. Now, I was a man staring at a ghost, mourning a boy who was at that very moment being lost to me all over again, in a different house, at a different party, but in exactly the same way. My grand strategy, my intricate web of manipulation, had been nothing more than a child’s sandcastle, built with frantic determination against an incoming tide. And the tide was here.

It was well after two in the morning when I heard his key in the lock. My body went rigid, every muscle tensed for the confrontation. I schooled my features into a mask of calm curiosity, the patient spymaster waiting for his agent’s report. He walked in, and the first thing that hit me was the scent. It wasn't the overpowering stench of whiskey from the old timeline. He was sober, clear-eyed. But woven into the familiar smell of him was something new. A cool, floral perfume, elegant and expensive. It was the scent of a world I didn’t belong to, and it was on my Kaelo’s clothes. It was the scent of Anais. He looked at me, a faint, tired smile on his lips. He didn’t seem dazzled or drunk, but charged, as if he had just come from an important, draining meeting. He loosened his collar, his movements fluid and controlled.

“So,” I began, my voice a little too stiff. “How was the intelligence-gathering mission?” He met my gaze, and the look in his eyes was not one of a boy who had been to a party. It was the look of a man who had seen a new horizon. “It was… illuminating,” he said, sinking onto his bed. He didn't offer a simple report; he began to analyse, to deconstruct. He spoke of the casual power dynamics, the way conversations were a constant, subtle jockeying for status. He described Seb not as an arrogant fool, but as a tragic figure, trapped by his father’s expectations, his cynicism a flimsy defense against his own mediocrity. He was seeing them not as caricatures, but as people, and it terrified me. "And the cousin?" I asked, forcing the question out. "The one whose party it was."

A different light came into Kaelo's eyes, a spark of genuine intellectual excitement that was far more dangerous than simple infatuation. "Anais," he said, the name soft on his tongue. "She's not like the others, Jona. She's… formidable." He sat up, leaning forward, suddenly energized. "We talked for almost an hour. She cornered me, started asking about Strathmore, what I was studying. I mentioned Nairobi Unlocked, almost as a joke, and she didn't laugh. She got this incredibly focused look in her eyes. She asked about our business model, our target demographic, our revenue streams. She called it a 'disruptive local enterprise'." He delivered the phrase with a kind of reverence, as if Anais had given our small dream a name he had never dared to imagine for it. He saw it as validation from a worthy source. I saw it as the first act of a hostile takeover.

"She sounds like she was interviewing you," I said, my voice sharp with a sarcasm I couldn't contain. "That's exactly what it felt like," Kaelo agreed, completely missing my point. "It was like sparring. She's got a mind like a steel trap. Her father runs one of the biggest private equity firms in East Africa. She's been sitting in on board meetings since she was sixteen. She understands money and power in a way we can only read about in textbooks. She thinks Nairobi Unlocked has potential. Real potential, Jona. She thinks we’re thinking too small." The phrase, my phrase, coming from her mouth via his, felt like a violation. She was stealing my script, rewriting my influence, replacing my voice in his head with her own.

I stood up, unable to sit still. The room felt too small, the air too thin. "And what did you tell her, Kaelo? Did you tell her about our mission? Did you tell her you were a spy in her camp?" The accusation was naked, stripped of all pretense of strategy. He looked at me, his brief excitement draining away, replaced by a weary frustration. "Of course not. I'm not an idiot. But I'm not a fool either. You can't learn anything if you’re not willing to engage. She’s not the enemy, Jonas. She’s… a resource. An incredible one. We need people like her if we’re ever going to build our own table. Or did you think we were going to do it all with handcarts and charm?"

The chasm between us yawned open in that moment, wider and deeper than it had ever been. He saw a powerful ally. I saw the woman who, in another life, had looked on with bored amusement as he amputated himself from his family, his home, his very soul. But this Anais was more dangerous. She wasn't just a beautiful, cold distraction. She was a strategist. She wouldn't pull him away with parties and pretty promises; she would colonize his ambition, merge his dreams with hers, and make him believe it was his own idea. He wouldn't be a prize she had won at a fair; he would be a willing partner in his own absorption. I looked at the boy I had worked so tirelessly to save, and I saw a stranger looking back at me, his eyes shining with the reflected light of a different, brighter flame. The mission was over. My agent had defected. And as he turned away from me, pulling off the shirt that smelled of her, the silence that settled between our beds was no longer an absence of sound. It was the sound of a future I had failed to prevent, snapping firmly into place.

The days that followed were a masterclass in psychological warfare, and I was losing. Anais did not descend upon our lives like a storm; she seeped in like a rising water table, silent and insidious, until we were all standing in it. Her name became a constant refrain in Kaelo’s evening reports. Anais had suggested a book on venture capital. Anais had an uncle who knew someone on the tourism board. Anais had explained the tax implications of formalizing the business. She was a ghost in our machine, an invisible third partner whose opinions held more weight than my own carefully researched facts. He presented her insights not as betrayals, but as valuable intelligence gathered from his 'mission', forcing me into the untenable position of a commander who could not fault his agent for being too successful.

The physical manifestation of her influence arrived on a Thursday evening. Kaelo came home not with his usual textbook-filled backpack, but with a sleek, silver laptop that looked alien on our worn wooden desk. It was a loaner from Anais, he explained, so they could work on a "proper proposal" for Nairobi Unlocked. He opened it, and the screen glowed with a crisp, bright light that made our humble lamp look yellow and weak. On the screen was a PowerPoint presentation, the title slide emblazoned with a professionally designed logo I had never seen before: 'NU-XPERIENCE', written in a sharp, minimalist font. The 'Nairobi Unlocked' name, our name, was gone, relegated to a small, nostalgic subtitle. I stared at the screen, a cold, hollow feeling spreading through my chest. It was the sterile, corporate language of the world we were supposed to be fighting, and it was being presented to me as progress.

“She thinks ‘Nairobi Unlocked’ sounds a bit… rustic,” Kaelo said, his eyes fixed on the screen, his voice alight with the thrill of this new, polished vision. “NU-XPERIENCE is slicker. More global. She’s already drafted a new business plan. Look.” He clicked through the slides. The images of Gikomba market and dusty city streets were gone, replaced by stock photos of smiling, multi-ethnic models sipping cocktails on rooftop bars. Our target market had been redefined as ‘High-Value Urban Explorers’. The tours were now ‘Curated Immersion Packages’. Our philosophy, once a rebellion against the sanitized tourist experience, had been neatly packaged and commodified into exactly that. It was our soul, professionally designed, expertly branded, and sold back to us at a premium. Every click of the mouse was a nail in the coffin of the world we had built together in that room.

"This isn't us, Kaelo," I said, my voice barely a whisper. "This is them. This is everything we said we would never become." He finally turned from the glowing screen to look at me, and the familiar impatience was back in his eyes, sharper now. "No, Jonas. This is us, but smarter. This is us with a real chance. Anais says a business built on charm can’t scale. You need a brand. You need a structure. You need capital. This proposal… she thinks her father's firm might be interested in providing seed money. Real money, Jona. Enough to get an office, to hire staff, to be a real company." The lie I had told him, that he was a spy gathering weapons, had been turned on its head. He had gone into the enemy camp and returned convinced that their weapons were better, and that the only way to win was to join their army. He wasn't just my agent anymore. He was hers.

The inevitable meeting was framed as a formality. “She wants to meet you properly,” Kaelo announced a few days later, his tone casual, as if discussing a trip to the market. “She wants the whole team to be on the same page before we approach any investors. She suggested we all meet for coffee. The café in Karen. On Saturday.” The location was a deliberate power play, a summons to her court. My stomach churned with a mixture of dread and fury. It was a test, a challenge, and to refuse would be to abdicate my position entirely, to admit that I was too scared to even show up to the battle for my own life. It would prove her point before she even opened her mouth: that I was small, provincial, and afraid of the world she inhabited so effortlessly. "Fine," I said, my voice tight. "I'll be there." Kaelo looked relieved, as if he had feared a fight. He didn't understand that the fight had already happened, and I had already lost. This was merely the formal signing of the surrender treaty.

Walking into that Karen café for the second time felt like returning to the scene of a crime. The memory of my own humiliation was a phantom limb, aching with remembered pain. Anais was already there, seated at a prime table overlooking the garden. She wasn't beautiful in the way a statue is, as I had remembered from my other life; she was beautiful in the way a hunting hawk is, all sleek lines and focused, intelligent eyes that missed nothing. She stood as we approached, her smile warm and welcoming, a perfectly calibrated expression that immediately put me on the defensive. She was dressed in simple, elegant linen, and the cool, floral scent I remembered from Kaelo’s shirt was a subtle, confident aura around her. She shook my hand, her grip firm, her sea-glass eyes meeting mine without a flicker of condescension. “Jonas,” she said, her voice a low, pleasant melody. “It is so good to finally meet you. Kaelo has told me so much about you. You’re the brains of the operation, the one who makes everything work.”

The compliment was a perfectly aimed dart, designed to both flatter and define me. I was the 'brains', the back-room technician, the logistical support for the visionaries. We sat, and she immediately took control of the conversation, not with aggression, but with an effortless, inclusive authority. She spoke directly to me, asking intelligent, insightful questions about my budgeting, my scheduling, my risk assessments. She listened intently, nodding, her expression one of deep respect. She made me feel seen, heard, and valued. And that was the most terrifying thing of all. This wasn't the cold, dismissive caricature I had built up in my mind. She was disarming me with respect, dismantling my defenses with genuine intellectual curiosity. She wasn’t dismissing my world; she was absorbing it, learning its language so she could translate it into her own.

Then, she turned her focus to the future, to the PowerPoint presentation Kaelo had already shown me. "I hope you don’t feel I’ve overstepped," she said, her gaze steady and sincere. "But I see such incredible potential in what you two have built. It’s raw, it's authentic, and it's exactly what the market is missing. My only thought was how to protect that authenticity as we scale. How do we grow without losing the magic?" She used the word 'we' constantly, a verbal sleight of hand that seamlessly inserted her into our past and future. Kaelo sat beside her, nodding in agreement, his eyes shining with adoration for her brilliant mind. He looked at the two of us, at his brilliant friend and his brilliant new partner, as if he were a proud father who had just brokered a perfect marriage. He couldn't see that I was the dowry, the territory being handed over in the alliance.

She laid out the vision, her vision, for 'our' company. It was flawless, logical, and irrefutable. She had answers for everything, from legal structures to marketing demographics. And with every logical point she made, I felt myself shrinking, my own contributions, my own identity, being quietly written out of the story. I was the co-founder, the partner, the other half of Kaelo’s world. In the space of one hour, over one cup of overpriced coffee, she had expertly and smilingly demoted me to the role of a future Chief Operating Officer. A vital role, a respected role, but a role in her company. A salaried employee in the empire she would build with the man I loved. I sat in silence, the coffee bitter in my mouth, listening to the sound of my life being rewritten by a beautiful, smiling, formidable stranger. I had come to fight a battle, but she had greeted me at the border with a promotion and a new uniform. And Kaelo, my Kaelo, saw it only as a victory.

The matatu ride home was a study in dissonance. Kaelo, seated beside me, was a live wire, thrumming with the energy of the meeting. He talked in a low, excited voice about growth projections and target audiences, using Anais’s corporate jargon as if he had been born speaking it. He was a cartographer excitedly describing a map to a new world, utterly oblivious to the fact that the man beside him was watching his own world burn to the ground in the reflection of the bus window. I stared out at the familiar, chaotic blur of Ngong Road, the vibrant storefronts and streams of people feeling more real and more precious than ever. Kaelo was describing a future of clean lines, of scalable models and projected returns. I was mourning the beautiful, messy, unprofitable present he was so eager to pave over. Every word he spoke was a eulogy for us, and he thought he was delivering a victory speech.

Back in our room, the silver laptop sat on the desk like a tombstone. Kaelo opened it immediately, its cold, white light bathing his face and casting the rest of our small, warm world into shadow. He looked like a stranger, an emissary from the slick, sterile future Anais was building for him. He was no longer my Kaelo, the boy who hummed off-key and was scared of moths. He was the CEO of NU-XPERIENCE, a man who saw our shared past as a charming but inefficient prototype. He clicked open a document, a meticulously formatted corporate structure that Anais had emailed him. He was so absorbed, so radiant with purpose, that he didn't notice the silence that had fallen between us, a silence as profound and final as the closing of a vault door.

"Look at this, Jona," he said, his voice full of reverent awe as he pointed at the screen. "Anais mapped out the whole five-year plan. She’s created a full C-suite. She sees you as Chief Operating Officer. The engine room, she called it. She says your attention to detail and logistical genius are exactly what a visionary CEO like me needs to stay grounded." The words, 'a visionary CEO like me', were not spoken with arrogance, but with a simple, breathtaking statement of fact as he now understood it. He had accepted his new title, his new role, his new identity. And in the same breath, he had accepted mine. I was the engine room. A vital, necessary, but ultimately subordinate piece of machinery in the grand vehicle he and Anais would be driving. The last vestiges of our partnership, of our equality, were gone, replaced by a neat box on an organisational chart she had drawn.

I stood up from my bed, the movement slow, deliberate. My body felt heavy, disconnected, an automaton running on the last fumes of a dying will. I walked over to the desk and looked down at the glowing screen, at the sterile flowchart that laid out the death of my life. “Our dream didn’t have a CEO, Kaelo,” I said, my voice unnervingly calm, a flat line in the charged atmosphere of the room. “It didn’t have a COO. It had you. And it had me. It had this room, and a pile of notebooks, and an idea that was ours.” He looked up at me, his focus finally pulled from the screen. The excitement in his face was clouded by a flicker of confusion, then a familiar wave of impatience. He didn’t understand why I was failing to celebrate this incredible stroke of luck, this quantum leap forward.

"What is wrong with you, Jonas?" he asked, his voice rising in frustration. "This is it! This is the bigger table you talked about! Anais is handing us the tools to build it, and all you can do is stand there and look like someone just shot your dog. This is our chance to win, to be something more than just two boys with a handcart. Why are you fighting it so hard? Are you that scared of success?" The accusation, that I was afraid, that I was the one holding us back, was the final injustice. He saw my grief as cowardice, my loyalty to our shared past as a failure of imagination. He saw Anais as a saviour, and me as an anchor holding him to the shabby shoreline he was now destined to leave. He truly, genuinely could not see what he was sacrificing.

And in that moment, I knew that all my strategies, all my manipulations, all my carefully constructed lies had been for nothing. I had tried to control the future, to divert the river, but I had only succeeded in changing the nature of the flood. There was only one weapon I had left, one truth I hadn't used. The raw, messy, unprofessional, unscalable truth. “Because ‘us’ is the only thing I ever cared about!” The words tore out of my throat, ragged and bleeding. The calmness shattered, and everything I had been holding back for this entire second life came pouring out. "Not the business! Not the money! Not building some stupid table for a world I hate! Just us! You and me! Here, in this room!"

I was breathing heavily, my fists clenched, my whole body trembling. Kaelo stared at me, his frustration washed away by sheer shock. He looked utterly bewildered, as if I had suddenly started speaking a language he’d never heard. This was not part of the plan. This was not on any spreadsheet. I took a step closer, my voice dropping to a desperate, trembling whisper, the final confession. "I am not your brother, Kaelo. I have never, not for one single day, felt like your brother." The ghost of our last fight in the other timeline was here, real and breathing and terrible. His face paled, the dawning, horrified comprehension beginning to flicker in his eyes, just as it had before. But I couldn't stop. I had to burn it all down to see if anything was left in the ashes. "I love you. Do you understand? Not like a brother. And she is taking you away from me, and you are letting her do it, and you're calling it progress. You call her a resource. You call me your COO. But what am I, Kaelo? What were we?"

The questions hung in the air, vibrating with years of repressed longing and a new, terrible agony. The laptop screen glowed between us, a silent, silver witness. On it, the NU-XPERIENCE logo pulsed softly, the symbol of his bright new future. Kaelo’s mouth opened slightly, but no sound came out. The confident CEO was gone, the cynical spy was gone.
